member.name: T:Au.Types.AFFlags
member.summary: Flags for and similar functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.Reverse
member.summary: Search in reverse order. It can make faster. When control class or id is specified in the prop argument, controls are searched not in reverse order. Only accessible objects in them are searched in reverse order.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.HiddenToo
member.summary: The accessible object can be invisible. Without this flag skips objects that are invisible (have state INVISIBLE) or are descendants of invisible WINDOW, DOCUMENT, PROPERTYPAGE, GROUPING, ALERT, MENUPOPUP. Regardless of this flag, always skips invisible standard objects of nonclient area: TITLEBAR, MENUBAR, SCROLLBAR, GRIP.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.MenuToo
member.summary: Always search in MENUITEM. Without this flag skips MENUITEM descendant objects (for speed), unless role is MENUITEM or MENUPOPUP or searching in web page.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.ClientArea
member.summary: Search only in the client area of the window or control. Skips the title bar, standard menubars and scrollbars. Searches only in the client area root object (but will not find the object itself). When control class or id is specified in the prop argument, this flag is applied to these controls. Not applied to other controls. Don't use this flag when searching in Acc or web page (role prefix "web:" etc) or with flag UIA.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.NotInProc
member.summary: Search without loading dll into the target process. Disadvantages: 1. Much slower. 2. Some properties are not supported, for example HTML attributes (while searching and later). 3. And more. Even without this flag, the default search method is not used with Windows Store app windows, console windows, most Java windows, windows of protected processes and processes of higher UAC integrity level, Firefox web page if its multiprocess feature is not disabled. Some windows have child controls that belong to a different process or thread than the window. Example - Internet Explorer. When searching in such windows, the default search method is not used when searching in these controls. Workaround - find the control(s) and search in it/them. For it can be used one of: 1. With Internet Explorer use role prefix "web:". 2. Find the control with and search in it. 3. Use . Don't need this flag when searching in Acc (then it is inherited from the Acc variable). See also: .

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.UIA
member.summary: Use UI Automation API. Need this flag to find objects in windows that don't support accessible objects but support UI Automation elements. Examples of such windows: Microsoft Edge web browser (web page), JavaFX applications. Objects found with this flag never have HtmlX properties, but can have . This flag can be used with most other windows too. Don't use this flag when searching in Acc (then it is inherited from the Acc variable) or web page (role prefix "web:" etc). See also: .

member.name: T:Au.Types.Native
member.summary: Windows API types and constants used with public functions (parameters etc) of this library. Also several helper functions.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Native.ClearError
member.summary: Calls API SetLastError(0), which clears the Windows API error code of this thread. Need it before calling some functions if you want to use or GetErrorMessage.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Native.SetError(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API SetLastError, which sets the Windows API error code of this thread.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Native.GetError
member.summary: Gets the Windows API error code of this thread. Calls .
member.remarks:
Many Windows API functions, when failed, set an error code. Code 0 means no error. It is stored in an internal thread-specific int variable. But only if the API declaration's DllImport attribute has SetLastError = true. Some functions of this library simply call these API functions and don't throw exception when API fail. For example, most Wnd propery-get functions. When failed, they return false/0/null/empty. Then you can call Native.GetError to get the error code. Also you can use GetErrorMessage.
Most of these functions set the code only when failed, and don't clear old error code when succeeded. Therefore may need to call before.
Windows API error code definitions and documentation are not included in this library. You can look for them in API function documentation on the internet.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Native.GetErrorMessage
member.summary: Gets the text message of the Windows API error code of this thread. Returns null if the code is 0. The string always ends with ".".

member.name: M:Au.Types.Native.GetErrorMessage(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the text message of a Windows API error code. Returns null if errorCode is 0. The string always ends with ".".

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIFlags.WindowDC
member.summary: Get pixels from the device context (DC) of the window client area, not from screen DC. Not used when area is Bitmap. Notes: Usually much faster. Can get pixels from window parts that are covered by other windows or offscreen. But not from hidden and minimized windows. Does not work on Windows 7 if Aero theme is turned off. Then this flag is ignored. If the window is DPI-scaled, the image must be captured from its non-scaled version. Cannot find images in some windows (including Windows Store apps), and in some window parts (glass). All pixels captured from these windows/parts are black.

member.summary: When the image argument specifies multiple images, all they must exist, else result is "not found". The result rectangle is of the last image. To get all rectangles, use the also parameter: also: t => { rectList.Add(t.Rect); return true; }.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXMatch
member.summary: Regular expression match info. Used with class functions and String extension methods like .
member.remarks: Contains info about a regular expression match found in the subject string: index, length, substring, etc. Also contains an array of group matches, as . Groups are regular expression parts enclosed in (), except (?...). Group matches can be accessed like array elements. Group 0 is whole match. Group 1 is the first group. See examples.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.GroupCountPlusOne
member.summary: The number of groups in the regular expression, + 1 for the whole match.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Index
member.summary: Start offset of the match in the subject string. The same as that of group 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.EndIndex
member.summary: + . The same as that of group 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Length
member.summary: Length of the match in the subject string. The same as that of group 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Value
member.summary: The match (substring) in the subject string. The same as that of group 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Subject
member.summary: The subject string in which this match was found.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RXMatch.ToString
member.summary: Returns .

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.IndexNoK
member.summary: Start offset of whole match regardless of \K. When the regular expression contains \K, this is different (less) than .

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Mark
member.summary: The name of a found mark, or null. Marks can be inserted in regular expression pattern like (*MARK:name) or (*:name). After a full successful match, it is the last mark encountered on the matching path through the pattern. After a "no match" or a partial match, it is the last encountered mark. For example, consider this pattern: "^(*MARK:A)((*MARK:B)a|b)c". When it matches "bc", the mark is A. The B mark is "seen" in the first branch of the group, but it is not on the matching path. On the other hand, when this pattern fails to match "bx", the mark is B.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Exists
member.summary: Gets the return value of the call. Can be false only when the function returned false but a mark is available (see ). Otherwise, when the function returns flase, it returns null instead of a RXMatch object. When false, all properties except Exists and Mark have undefined values or throw exception.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.IsPartial
member.summary: Returns true if this match is partial. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Item(System.Int32)

member.param: 1-based group index, or 0 for whole match.

member.summary: Finds a named group and returns its 1-based index. Returns -1 if not found.
member.param: Group name.
Receives true if more than 1 group have this name.
member.remarks: If more than 1 group have this name, prefers the first group that matched ( is true).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RXMatch.ExpandReplacement(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the expanded version of the specified replacement pattern.
member.param: Replacement pattern. Can consist of any combination of literal text and substitutions like $1. Supports .NET regular expression substitution syntax. See . Also replaces $* with the name of the last encountered mark.
member.remarks: Works like . See also: .

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXGroup
member.summary: Regular expression group match info. Used with , and some String extension methods.
member.remarks:
Groups are regular expression parts enclosed in (). Except non-capturing parts, like (?:...) and (?options). A RXGroup variable contains info about a group found in the subject string: index, length, substring.
Some groups specified in regular expression may not exist in the subject string even if it matches the regular expression. For example, regular expression "A(\d+)?B" matches string "AB", but group (\d+) does not exist. Then is false, -1, 0, null.
When a group matches multiple times, the RXGroup variable contains only the last instance. For example, if subject is "begin 12 345 67 end" and regular expression is (\d+ )+, value of group 1 is "67". If you need all instances ("12", "345", "67"), instead use .NET and . Also you can get all instances with .
Examples and more info: , .

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXGroup.Index
member.summary: Start offset of the group match in the subject string.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXGroup.Length
member.summary: Length of the group match in the subject string.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXGroup.Value
member.summary: String value of the group match in the subject string.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXGroup.Exists
member.summary: Returns true if the group exists in the subject string, false if does not exist. More info in help. Example in help.
member.remarks: Other ways to detect it: if a group does not exist, its Index is -1 and Value is null.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RXGroup.ToString
member.summary: Returns .

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXMore
member.summary: Rarely used parameters for class functions.
member.remarks:
The constructor allows you to set initial values of fields. You can modify them later if need. Regex_ functions don't modify them.
The start/end fields can be used to specify part of subject string. When a function has parameter group, the start/end fields don't depend on it; they are used to specify where to search for whole match.

member.name: F:Au.Types.RXMore.start
member.summary: The start index (offset) in the subject string. Default 0. Valid values are from 0 to (including) subject length. The subject part before it is not ignored if regular expression starts with a lookbehind assertion or anchor, eg ^ or \b or (?<=...). Instead of ^ you can use \G. More info in PCRE documentation topic pcre2api, chapter "The string to be matched by pcre2_match()".

member.name: F:Au.Types.RXMore.end
member.summary: The end index (offset) in the subject string. As if the string ends here. If negative (default -1), is used subject string length. Else valid values are from to (including) subject length.

member.name: F:Au.Types.RXMore.matchFlags
member.summary: Options. The same options also can be set when calling Regex_ constructor. Constructor's flags and matchFlags are added, which means that matchFlags cannot unset flags set when calling constructor.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RXMore.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.Types.RXMatchFlags)
member.summary: Sets field values. If is -1 (default), will be used subject string length.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXCalloutFunc
member.summary: Delegate type of callout callback function. See .

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXCalloutData
member.summary: Managed version of PCRE API struct pcre2_callout_block. When you set , your callout function's parameter is of this type. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout. Most properties are pcre2_callout_block fields as documented in PCRE help. Other properties and methods are easier/safer versions of unsafe fields like offset_vector.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.Result
member.summary: Sets the return value of the callout function, as documented in PCRE help topic pcre2callout. Default 0. If 1, matching fails at the current point, but the testing of other matching possibilities goes ahead, just as if a lookahead assertion had failed. If -1 (PCRE2_ERROR_NOMATCH), the match function returns false (no match). Values less tan -2 are PCRE error codes and cause exception.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.callout_number
member.summary: Callout number, eg 5 for "(?C5)". More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.capture_top
member.summary: One more than the number of the highest numbered captured group so far. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.capture_last
member.summary: The number of the most recently captured group. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.start_match
member.summary: The offset within the subject string at which the current match attempt started. But depends on \K etc. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.current_position
member.summary: The current offset within the subject string.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.pattern_position
member.summary: The offset in the regular expression to the next item to be matched.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.next_item_length
member.summary: The length of the next item to be processed in the regular expression. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.callout_string_offset
member.summary: The callout string offset in the regular expression. Used with callouts like "(?C'calloutString')". More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.callout_string
member.summary: The callout string, eg "xyz" for "(?C'xyz')". More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.mark
member.summary: The most recently passed (*MARK), (*PRUNE), or (*THEN) item in the match, or null if no such items have been passed. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXFlags
member.summary: Flags for constructor. Documented in PCRE help topic pcre2api.
member.remarks:
Many options also can be specified in regular expression (RE):
These can be anywhere in RE: (?i) CASELESS, (?m) MULTILINE, (?s) DOTALL, (?n) NO_AUTO_CAPTURE, (?x) EXTENDED, (?xx) EXTENDED_MORE, (?J) DUPNAMES, (?U) UNGREEDY. Can be multiple, like (?ms). Can be unset, like (?-i). RE "\Qtext\E" is like RE "text" with flag LITERAL.
Instead of ANCHORED can be used \A or \G at the start of RE. Or ^, except in multiline mode.
Instead of ENDANCHORED can be used \z at the end of RE. Or $, except in multiline mode.
Flag UTF is implicitly added if RE contains non-ASCII characters and there is no flag NEVER_UTF.
These must be at the very start and are named like flags: (*UTF), (*UCP), (*NOTEMPTY), (*NOTEMPTY_ATSTART), (*NO_AUTO_POSSESS), (*NO_DOTSTAR_ANCHOR), (*NO_START_OPT).
More info in PCRE syntax reference.
Some of RXFlags flags also exist in . You can set them either when calling Regex_ constructor or when calling Regex_ functions that have parameter more. You can use different flags for each function call with the same Regex_ variable.

member.name: F:Au.Types.RXFlags.UTF
member.summary: Fully support Unicode text (case-insensitivity etc). More info in PCRE documentation topic pcre2unicode. This flag is implicitly added if regular expression contains non-ASCII characters and there is no flag NEVER_UTF.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXMatchFlags
member.summary: Flags for and other class functions. Documented in PCRE help topic pcre2api.
member.remarks: These flags also exist in (Regex_ constructor flags). You can set them either when calling constructor or when calling other functions.

member.name: T:Au.Types.Types`2
member.summary: Used for method parameters that accept one of two types.
member.remarks:
Some methods have one or several parameters that must be one of several types. There are several ways of implementing such functions. 1. Overloaded methods. However some programmers often don't like it, because in some cases need to create many overloads, then maintain their documentation. Also then method users have to spend much time to find the correct overload. 2. Generic methods. However in most cases the compiler cannot protect from using an unsupported type. Also then method users don't see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. 3. Using the Object type for the parameter. However then the compiler does not protect from using an unsupported type. Also then method users don't see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. Also slower, especially with value types (need boxing). 4. Using this type for the parameter. It does not have the above problems.
When a parameter is of type Types<T1, T2>, method users can pass only values of type T1 or T2, else compiler error. They see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. Also there are similar types that can be used to support more parameter types:
To support null (for example for optional parameters), use nullable. See examples.

member.name: T:Au.Types.Coord
member.summary: Contains x or y coordinate. Used for parameters of functions like Mouse.Move, Wnd.Move. Allows to easily specify coordinates of these types: normal, reverse (from right or bottom of a rectangle), fractional (fraction of width or height of a rectangle), null. Also has functions to convert to normal coodinates.

member.name: T:Au.Types.Coord.CoordType
member.summary: Coord variable value type.

member.name: F:Au.Types.Coord.CoordType.None
member.summary: No value. Assigned null or default(Coord).

member.name: F:Au.Types.Coord.CoordType.Normal
member.summary: is pixel offset from left or top of a rectangle.

member.name: F:Au.Types.Coord.CoordType.Reverse
member.summary: is pixel offset from right or bottom of a rectangle, towards left or top.

member.name: F:Au.Types.Coord.CoordType.Fraction
member.summary: is fraction of a rectangle, where 0.0 is left or top, and 1.0 is right or bottom (outside of the rectangle).

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Type
member.summary: Value type.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Value
member.summary: Non-fraction value.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.FractionValue
member.summary: Fraction value.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.IsEmpty
member.summary: Returns true if Type == None (when assigned null or default(Coord)).

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.op_Implicit(System.Int32)~Au.Types.Coord
member.summary: Creates Coord of Normal type.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.op_Implicit(Au.Types.JustNull)~Au.Types.Coord
member.summary: Infrastructure. Allows to assign null.
member.param: null.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.Reverse(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates Coord of Reverse type. Value 0 is at the right or bottom, and does not belong to the rectangle. Positive values are towards left or top.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.Fraction(System.Double)
member.summary: Creates Coord of Fraction type. Value 0.0 is the left or top of the rectangle. Value 1.0 is the right or bottom of the rectangle. Values <0.0 and >=1.0 are outside of the rectangle.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Center
member.summary: Returns Fraction(0.5).

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Max
member.summary: Returns Reverse(0). This point will be outside of the rectangle. See also .

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.MaxInside
member.summary: Returns Reverse(1). This point will be inside of the rectangle, at the very right or bottom, assuming that the rectangle is not empty.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.NormalizeInRect(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.RECT,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts fractional/reverse coordinates to normal coordinates in a rectangle.
member.param: X coordinate relative to r.
Y coordinate relative to r.
The rectangle.
Use only width and height of r. If false, the function adds r offset (left and top).
If x or y is default(Coord), use Coord.Center. Not used with widthHeight.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.NormalizeInWindow(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns normal coordinates relative to the client area of a window. Converts fractional/reverse coordinates etc.
member.param: X coordinate relative to the client area of w.
Y coordinate relative to the client area of w.
The window.
x y are relative to the entire w rectangle, not to its client area.
If x or y is default(Coord), use Coord.Center.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.Normalize(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.CoordOptions,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns normal coordinates relative to the primary screen. Converts fractional/reverse coordinates etc.
member.param: X coordinate relative to the specified screen (default - primary).
Y coordinate relative to the specified screen (default - primary).
Can be used to specify screen (see ) and/or whether x y are relative to the work area.
Use only width and height of the screen rectangle. If false, the function adds its offset (left and top, which can be nonzero if using the work area or a non-primary screen).

member.summary: Screen and other options for functions that accept coordinates as .

member.summary: Screen index or anything that can be converted to with .

member.name: P:Au.Types.CoordOptions.WorkArea
member.summary: If true, coordinates are relative to the work area, not to whole screen.

member.summary: More parameters for .

member.name: F:Au.Types.SRMore.WorkingDirectory
member.summary: Initial working directory for the new process. Some programs look for their files in the working directory and fail to start if it is not the program's directory. If null (default), the function gets parent directory path from the file parameter, if possible (if full path is specified or found). If this is "" or invalid or the function cannot find full path, the new process will inherit the curent working directory of this process.

member.name: F:Au.Types.SRMore.Verb
member.summary: File's right-click menu command, also known as verb. For example "edit", "print", "properties". The default verb is bold in the menu. Not all menu items will work. Some may have different name than in the menu. Use verb "RunAs" for "Run as administrator".

member.name: F:Au.Types.SRMore.OwnerWindow
member.summary: Owner window for error message boxes. Also, new window should be opened on the same screen. However many programs ignore it.

member.name: F:Au.Types.SRMore.WindowState
member.summary: Preferred window state. Many programs ignore it.

member.name: F:Au.Types.SRMore.NeedProcessHandle
member.summary: Get process handle, if possible. The property will contain it.

member.name: P:Au.Types.SRMore.ProcessHandle
member.summary: This is an [Out] value. When the function returns, if was set to true, contains process handle in a variable. null if did not start new process (eg opened the document in an existing process) or did not get process handle for some other reason. Note: WaitHandle is disposable.

member.name: T:Au.Types.AuException
member.summary: The base exception used in this library. Some constructors support Windows API error code. Then Message will contain its error description. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If does not end with ".", appends ".".

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor
member.summary: Sets Message = "Failed.". Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Sets Message = message. Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets Message = "Failed. " + Native.GetErrorMessage(winApiErrorCode). Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : Native.GetError().

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + " " + Native.GetErrorMessage(winApiErrorCode). Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : Native.GetError().

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + "\r\n\t" + innerException.Message. Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + " " + Native.GetErrorMessage(winApiErrorCode) + "\r\n\t" + innerException.Message. Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : Native.GetError().

member.name: P:Au.Types.AuException.NativeErrorCode
member.summary: Gets the Windows API error code.

member.name: P:Au.Types.AuException.Message
member.summary: Gets error message.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AuException.FormattedMessage
member.summary: String created by FormatMessage(), which should be called by the Message override if null. Initially null.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.FormatMessage(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Formats error message. Sets and returns FormattedMessage. As base text, uses the text passed to the constructor (default "Failed."). If it starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If it ends with "*", replaces the "*" with commonPostfix if it is not empty. If then the message does not end with ".", appends ".". If appendMessage is null, uses Native.GetErrorMessage(NativeErrorCode) if NativeErrorCode not 0. If then appendMessage is not empty, appends " " and appendMessage. Also appends InnerException.Message in new tab-indented line if InnerException is not null.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.ThrowIfHresultNot0(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If errorCode is not 0, throws AuException that includes the code and its message. More info: .
member.param: Windows API error code or HRESULT.
Main message. The message of the error code will be appended to it.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.ThrowIfHresultNegative(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If errorCode is less than 0, throws AuException that includes the code and its message. More info: .
member.param: Windows API error code or HRESULT.
Main message. The message of the error code will be appended to it.

member.name: T:Au.Types.WndException
member.summary: Exception thrown mostly by functions.
member.remarks: Some constructors support Windows API error code. Then Message also will contain its error description. If error code ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE, Message also depends on whether the window handle is 0. If parameter 'winApiErrorCode' is 0 or not used: if the window handle is invalid, uses ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If ends with "*", replaces the "*" with " window.". If does not end with ".", appends ".".

member.name: M:Au.Types.WndException.#ctor(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. Sets Message = "Failed.".

member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE.

member.name: M:Au.Types.WndException.#ctor(Au.Wnd,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? Native.GetError() : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE). Sets Message = "Failed.".

member.name: M:Au.Types.WndException.#ctor(Au.Wnd,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? Native.GetError() : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE).

member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE.

member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? Native.GetError() : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE).

member.summary: Converts double to string. Uses invariant culture, therefore decimal point is always '.', not ',' etc. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Types.ExtensionMethods.IsEmpty_(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Returns true if t.Width <= 0 || t.Height <= 0. This extension method has been added because Rectangle.IsEmpty returns true only when all fields are 0, which is not very useful.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ExtensionMethods.Has_``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Returns true if this enum variable has flag(s) f (all bits). Compiled as inlined code (t & flag) == flags. The same as Enum.HasFlag, but much much faster. The enum type must be of size 4 (default).

member.name: M:Au.Types.ExtensionMethods.HasAny_``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Returns true if this enum variable has one or more flag bits specified in f. Compiled as inlined code (t & flags) != 0. This is different from Enum.HasFlag. The enum type must be of size 4 (default).

member.name: T:Au.Types.LPARAM
member.summary: Similar to IntPtr (can be 32-bit or 64-bit), but more useful for usually-non-pointer values, eg wParam/lParam of SendMessage. Unlike IntPtr: Has implicit casts from/to most integral types. Does not check overflow when casting from uint etc. IntPtr throws exception on overflow, which can create strange bugs.
member.remarks: There is no struct WPARAM. Use LPARAM instead, because it is the same in all cases except when casting to long or ulong (ambigous signed/unsigned). There is no cast operators for enum. When need, cast through int or uint. For Wnd cast through IntPtr.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RECT
member.summary: Contains rectangle coordinates. Unlike Rectangle, which contains fields for width and height and therefore cannot be used with Windows API functions, RECT contains fields for right and bottom and can be used with Windows API.

member.summary: Initializes this instance.
member.param: right or width, depending on .
bottom or height, depending on .
If true, used width/height. If false, used right/bottom.

member.summary: Sets fields like the constructor .

member.summary: Returns true if the rectangle is empty or invalid: right<=left || bottom<=top;

member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle contains the specified point.

member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle contains entire specified rectangle.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Inflate(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Makes this rectangle bigger or smaller: left-=dx; right+=dx; top-=dy; bottom+=dy; Use negative dx/dy to make the rectangle smaller. Note: too big negative dx/dy can make it invalid (right<left or bottom<top).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Intersect(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Replaces this rectangle with the intersection of itself and the specified rectangle. Returns true if the rectangles intersect. If they don't intersect, makes this RECT empty (IsEmpty would return true).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Intersect(Au.Types.RECT,Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns the intersection rectangle of two rectangles. If they don't intersect, returns empty rectangle (IsEmpty would return true).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.IntersectsWith(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle and another rectangle intersect.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Offset(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves this rectangle by the specified offsets: left+=dx; right+=dx; top+=dy; bottom+=dy; Negative dx moves to the left. Negative dy moves up.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Union(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Replaces this rectangle with the union of itself and the specified rectangle. Union is the smallest rectangle that contains two full rectangles. Returns true if finally this rectangle is not empty. If either rectangle is empty (Width or Height is <=0), the result is another rectangle. If both empty - empty rectangle.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Union(Au.Types.RECT,Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns the union of two rectangles. Union is the smallest rectangle that contains two full rectangles. If either rectangle is empty (Width or Height is <=0), the result is another rectangle. If both empty - empty rectangle.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.MoveInScreen(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this rectangle to the specified coordinates in the specified screen, and ensures that whole rectangle is in screen. Final rectangle coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen. If null - screen center. You also can use Coord.Reverse etc.
Y coordinate in the specified screen. If null - screen center. You also can use Coord.Reverse etc.
Use this screen (see ). If null (default), uses the primary screen.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
If part of rectangle is not in screen, move and/or resize it so that entire rectangle would be in screen. Default true.
member.remarks: This function can be used to calculate new window location before creating it. If window already exists, use .

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.EnsureInScreen(System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adjusts this rectangle to ensure that whole rectangle is in screen. Initial and final rectangle coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
member.param: Use this screen (see ). If null (default), uses screen of the rectangle (or nearest).
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
member.remarks: This function can be used to calculate new window location before creating it. If window already exists, use .

member.summary: Converts color from ARGB (0xAARRGGBB) to ABGR (0xAABBGGRR) or vice versa (swaps the red and blue bytes). ARGB is used in .NET, GDI+ and HTML/CSS. ABGR is used by most Windows native API.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.Brightness0to255
member.summary: Calculates color's perceived brightness. Returns a value in range 0 (brightness of black color) to 1 (brightness of white color).
member.remarks: Unlike Color.GetBrightness, this function gives different weights for red, green and blue components. Does not use alpha.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.AdjustLuminance(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Changes color's luminance (makes darker or brighter). Returns new color. Does not modify this variable.
member.param: The luminance in units of 0.1 percent of the range (which depends on totalRange). Can be from -1000 to 1000.

If true, n is in the whole luminance range (from minimal to maximal possible). If false, n is in the range from current luminance of the color to the maximal (if n positive) or minimal (if n negative) luminance.
member.remarks: Calls API ColorAdjustLuma. Does not change hue and saturation. Does not use alpha.

member.name: T:Au.Types.Wildex
member.summary: This class implements wildcard expression parsing and matching (comparing). Typically used in 'find' functions. For example, Wnd.Find uses it to compare window name, class name and program. The 'find' function creates a Wildex instance (which parses the wildcard expression), then calls for each item (eg window) to compare some its property text.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Wildex.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Wildcard expression. Cannot be null (throws exception). "" will match "".

member.summary: Creates new Wildex from wildcard expression string. If the string is null, returns null.
member.param: Wildcard expression.

member.summary: Compares a string with the wildcard expression used to create this . Returns true if they match.
member.param: String. If null, returns false. If "", returns true if it was "" or "*" or a regular expression that matches "".

member.summary: The type of text (wildcard expression) used when creating the Wildex variable.

member.summary: Simple text (option t, or no *? characters and no t r R options). Match() calls .

member.summary: Wildcard (has *? characters and no t r R options). Match() calls .

member.summary: PCRE regular expression (option r). Match() calls .

member.summary: .NET egular expression (option R). Match() calls .

member.name: F:Au.Types.Wildex.WildType.Multi
member.summary: Multiple parts (option m). Match() calls Match() for each part (see ) and returns true if all negative (option n) parts return true (or there are no such parts) and some positive (no option n) part returns true (or there are no such parts). If you want to implement a different logic, call Match() for each element (instead of calling Match() for this variable).

member.name: T:Au.Types.WildexStruct
member.summary: A slim version of .
member.remarks: Has all the same capabilities as Wildex, but is just a struct of single pointer size. The pointer is Object that can be of one of these types: - if the assigned string was with wildcard expression options, like "**c text". To compare it with other strings, calls . - if the assigned string was without wildcard expression options. To compare it with other strings, calls with ignoreCase true. null - if was not assigned a non-null string.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WXYFlags.NeedWindow
member.summary: Need top-level window. If at that point is a control, gets its top-level parent. Don't use together with NeedControl. If none of flags NeedWindow and NeedControl are specified, the function gets exactly what is at that point (control or top-level window).

member.name: F:Au.Types.WXYFlags.NeedControl
member.summary: Need a control (child window). Returns default(Wnd) if there is no control at that point. Don't use together with NeedWindow. If none of flags NeedWindow and NeedControl are specified, the function gets exactly what is at that point (control or top-level window).

member.name: F:Au.Types.WXYFlags.Raw
member.summary: Just call API WindowFromPoint. Faster but less accurate with controls. Does not see disabled controls, does not prefer non-transparent controls. Not used with flag NeedWindow.

member.summary: 'flags' parameter of .

member.name: F:Au.Types.WFFlags.HiddenToo
member.summary: Can find hidden windows. See . Use this carefully. Always use className, not just name, because there are many hidden tooltip windows etc that could match the name.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WFFlags.SkipCloaked
member.summary: Skip cloaked windows. See . Cloaked are windows hidden not in the classic way, therefore Wnd.IsVisible does not detect it, but Wnd.IsCloaked detects. For example, windows on inactive Windows 10 virtual desktops; inactive Windows Store apps on Windows 8.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FAFlags.UseRawPath
member.summary: Pass path to the API as it is, without any normalizing and validating.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FAFlags.DoNotThrow
member.summary: If failed, return false and don't throw exception. Then, if you need error info, you can use . If the file/directory does not exist, it will return ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND or ERROR_PATH_NOT_FOUND or ERROR_NOT_READY. If failed and the native error code is ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED or ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION, the returned attributes will be (FileAttributes)(-1). The file probably exists but is protected so that this process cannot access and use it. Else attributes will be 0.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileProperties.LastAccessTimeUtc

member.name: T:Au.Types.FEFlags
member.summary: flags for .

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.AndSubdirectories
member.summary: Enumerate subdirectories too.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.AndSymbolicLinkSubdirectories
member.summary: Also enumerate symbolic link and mounted folder target directories. Use with AndSubdirectories.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.SkipHidden
member.summary: Skip files and subdirectories that have Hidden attribute.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.SkipHiddenSystem
member.summary: Skip files and subdirectories that have Hidden and System attributes (both). These files/directories usually are created and used only by the operating system. Drives usually have several such directories. Another example - thumbnail cache files. Without this flag the function skips only these hidden-system root directories when enumerating a drive: "$Recycle.Bin", "System Volume Information", "Recovery". If you want to include them too, use network path of the drive, for example @"\\localhost\D$\" for D drive.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.IgnoreAccessDeniedErrors
member.summary: If fails to get contents of the directory or a subdirectory because of its security settings, assume that the [sub]directory is empty. Without this flag then throws exception or calls errorHandler.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.DisableRedirection
member.summary: Temporarily disable file system redirection in this thread of this 32-bit process running on 64-bit Windows. Then you can enumerate the 64-bit System32 folder in your 32-bit process. Uses API Wow64DisableWow64FsRedirection. For vice versa (in 64-bit process enumerate the 32-bit System folder), instead use path Folders.SystemX86.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.UseRawPath
member.summary: Don't call (directoryPath) and don't throw exception for non-full path.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.NeedRelativePaths
member.summary: Let be path relative to the specified directory path. Like @"\name.txt" or @"\subdirectory\name.txt" instead of "name.txt".

member.name: T:Au.Types.FCFlags
member.summary: flags for and some other similar functions. Used only when copying directory.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FCFlags.SkipHiddenSystem
member.summary: Skip descendant files and directories that have Hidden and System attributes (both). They usually are created and used only by the operating system. Drives usually have several such directories. Another example - thumbnail cache files. They often are protected and would fail to copy, ruining whole copy operation. Without this flag the function skips only these hidden-system root directories when enumerating a drive: "$Recycle.Bin", "System Volume Information", "Recovery".

member.name: F:Au.Types.FCFlags.IgnoreAccessDeniedErrors
member.summary: If fails to get contents of the directory or a subdirectory because of its security settings, don't throw exception but assume that the [sub]directory is empty.

For example when renaming "file.txt" to "FILE.TXT".

member.name: T:Au.Acc
member.summary: Accessible object.
member.remarks:
Accessible objects (AO) are various user interface (UI) objects in windows and controls. For example buttons, links, list items. This class can find them, get properties, click, etc. Especially useful with web pages, because there are no controls. And many other windows don't use controls but support AO. But not all UI objects are AO.
An Acc instance holds an AO COM pointer (IAccessible) and a simple element id (int). Most Acc functions wrap IAccessible interface functions or/and related API.
Acc functions that get properties don't throw exception when the wrapped IAccessible/etc function failed (returned an error code of HRESULT type). Then they return "" (string properties), 0, false, null or empty collection, dependin on return type. Applications implement AOs differently, often with bugs, and their IAccessible interface functions return a variety of error codes. It's impossible to reliably detect whether the error code means a serious error or the property is merely unavailable. These Acc functions also set the last error code of this thread = the return value (HRESULT) of the IAccessible function, and callers can use to get it. If Native.GetError returns 1 (S_FALSE), in most cases it's not an error, just the property is unavailable. On error it will probably be a negative error code.
You can dispose Acc variables to release the COM object, but it is not necessary (GC will do it later).
An Acc variable cannot be used in multiple threads. Only Dispose can be called in any thread.
AOs are implemented and live in their applications. This class just communicates with them.
Many applications have various problems with their AOs: bugs, incorrect/nonstandard/partial implementation, or initially disabled. This class implements workarounds for known problems, where possible.
Known problematic applications:
Chrome web browser. Also Opera and other apps that use Chrome code; window class name is like "Chrome_WidgetWin_1".
Web page AOs initially are disabled (missing). Workarounds: Functions Find, Wait and FindAll enable it if used role prefix "web:" or "chrome:". Functions FromXY, FromMouse and Focused enable it if window class name starts with "Chrome". However Chrome does it lazily, therefore first time the functions often get wrong AO. Note: this auto-enabing may fail with future Chrome versions. Other ways to enable Chrome AOs: 1. Start Chrome with command line --force-renderer-accessibility. 2. In the future the script editor will have an option to enable Chrome AOs when it starts.
Some new web browser versions add new features or bugs that break something. AOs are especially vulnerable, because they are considered second-class citizens.
Firefox web browser.
By default, the Find function is 50-100 times slower than it could be. Also for this reason the Wait function consumes much CPU. And HTML attributes may be unavailable. See . Workaround: disable the Firefox multiprocess feature: open URL about:config, find browser.tabs.remote.autostart, set it = false, restart Firefox. If there is no such option, right-click and create it, as Boolean. If there are more than one similar options, set them all = false. Note: Firefox may reset it when upgrading or reinstalling, or even remove it in the future. If this does not work, google how to disable Firefox multiprocess.
When Firefox starts, its web page AOs are unavailable. It creates them only when somebody asks (eg function Find), but does it lazily, and Find at first fails. Workaround: use Wait, not Find.
Ocassionally Firefox briefly turns off its web page AOs. Workaround: use Wait, not Find. With other web browsers also it's better to use Wait.
Some new web browser versions add new features or bugs that break something. AOs are especially vulnerable, because they are considered second-class citizens.
Edge web browser, JavaFX and other applications that don't have true accessible objects but have UI Automation elements.
To find AOs in these applications, need flag .
Java applications that use AWT/Swing (window class name starts with "SunAwt").
Not supported on 32-bit OS.
Must be enabled Java Access Bridge (JAB). If JAB is disabled or does not work, the "Find accessible object" tool shows an "enable" link when you try to capture something in a Java window. The link calls Au.Tools.Form_Acc.Java.EnableDisableJabUI. Or you can enable JAB in Control Panel -> Ease of Access Center -> Use the computer without a display. Or use jabswitch.exe. Then restart Java apps. Also may need to restart apps that tried to use Java AOs.
Your process must have the same 32/64 bitness as the installed Java. To remove this limitation, install Java 32-bit and 64-bit (they coexist).
OpenOffice.
Often crashes after using AOs, usually when closing. Noticed in OpenOffice 4.1.4; may be fixed in newer versions.
LibreOffice.
AOs are unavailable unless this process is 32-bit (when LibreOffice is 64-bit). Also need flag .
In some windows, AO of some controls are not connected to AO of parent control. Then Find cannot find them if searches in whole window.
Workaround: search only in that control. For example, use prop "class" or id". If it's a web browser control, use role prefix "web:". Or find the control with and search in it. Or use .
AOs of many standard Windows controls have bugs when they are retrieved without loading dll into the target process (see ). Known bugs: 1. Toolbar buttons don't have Name in some cases. 2. and often don't work properly.
Workaround: don't use , or use .
Function Find is much slower when cannot load dll into the target process. More info: . Function Wait then consumes much more CPU.
If the process has different 32/64 bitness than this process, to load the dll is launched rundll32.exe, which makes slower by about 50 ms first time.
Currently this library does not support auto-scaled windows when using high DPI (text size 125%, 150% or more). If the target process is auto-scaled and this process isn't (or vice versa, or they have a different scaling factor), most coordinate-related functions don't work properly. For example, they get wrong AO rectangles.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.WndContainer
member.summary: Gets the container window or control of this accessible object. Uses API WindowFromAccessibleObject.
member.remarks: Returns default(Wnd) if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property, but some have bugs and can fail (return default(Wnd)) or return a wrong window.

member.summary: Gets the top-level window that contains this accessible object. Uses API WindowFromAccessibleObject and API GetAncestor.
member.remarks: Returns default(Wnd) if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property, but some have bugs and can return default(Wnd).

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Rect
member.summary: Gets location of this accessible object in screen.
member.remarks: Calls . Returns empty rectangle if failed or this property is unavailable. Supports . Most but not all objects support this property.

member.summary: Gets location of this accessible object in screen. Uses IAccessible.accLocation.
member.param: Receives object rectangle in screen coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.GetRect(Au.Types.RECT@,Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets location of this accessible object in the client area of window w. Uses IAccessible.accLocation and .
member.param: Receives object rectangle in w client area coordinates.
Window or control.
member.remarks: Returns false if failed or this property is unavailable. Supports . Most but not all objects support this property.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.RoleInt
member.summary: Gets standard non-string role, as enum AccROLE. Uses IAccessible.get_accRole.
member.remarks: Most objects have a standard role, as enum . Some objects have a custom role, usually as string, for example in web pages in Firefox and Chrome. Returns 0 if role is string or if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property. If failed, probably the object is invalid, for example its window was closed.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Role
member.summary: Gets standard or custom role, as string. Uses IAccessible.get_accRole.
member.remarks: Most objects have a standard role, as enum . Some objects have a custom role, usually as string, for example in web pages in Firefox and Chrome. For standard roles this function returns enum member name. For string roles - the string. For unknown non-string roles - the int value like "0" or "500". Returns "" if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property. If failed, probably the object is invalid, for example its window was closed.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.State
member.summary: Gets object state (flags). Uses IAccessible.get_accState.
member.remarks: Returns 0 if failed. Supports .

example.code: if(a.State.Has_(AccSTATE.INVISIBLE)) Print("has state INVISIBLE"); if(a.IsInvisible) Print("invisible");

member.name: P:Au.Acc.IsChecked
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state CHECKED.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.IsDisabled
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state UNAVAILABLE.
member.remarks: Does not check whether this object is in a disabled parent/ancestor object.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.IsFocused
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state FOCUSED.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.IsInvisible
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state INVISIBLE and does not have state OFFSCREEN.
member.remarks: If the object has both INVISIBLE and OFFSCREEN states, it is either invisible or just offscreen, depending on application etc. Then this function works like Find and similar functions: for most objects returns false (is visible), but for objects that have these roles returns true (invisible): WINDOW, DOCUMENT, PROPERTYPAGE, GROUPING, ALERT, MENUPOPUP. Does not check whether this object is in an invisible parent/ancestor object.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.IsOffscreen
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state OFFSCREEN.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.IsPassword

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Name
member.summary: Gets name. Uses IAccessible.get_accName.
member.remarks: Object name usually is its read-only text (eg button text, link text), or its adjacent read-only text (eg text label by this edit box). It usually does not change, therefore can be used to find or identify the object. Returns "" if name is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.LibNameOfWindow(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets of window/control w. Returns null if w invalid. Returns "" if failed to get name.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets value. Uses IAccessible.get_accValue or IAccessible.put_accValue.
member.remarks: Object value usually is its editable text or some other value that can be changed at run time, therefore in most cases it cannot be used to find or identify the object reliably. The 'get' function returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . Most objects don't support 'set'.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Description
member.summary: Gets description. Uses IAccessible.get_accDescription.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Acc.KeyboardShortcut
member.summary: Gets keyboard shortcut. Uses IAccessible.get_accKeyboardShortcut.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Acc.DefaultAction
member.summary: Gets default action. Uses IAccessible.get_accDefaultAction.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . If this is a Java accessible object, returns all actions that can be used with , like "action1, action2, action3", from which the first is considered default and is used by .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.DoAction
member.summary: Performs the object's default action (see ). Usually it is 'click', 'press' or similar. Uses IAccessible.accDoDefaultAction.
member.remarks: Fails if the object does not have a default action. Then you can use , or try , , and keyboard functions. The action can take long time, for example show a dialog. This function normally does not wait. It allows the caller to automate the dialog. If it waits, try or one of the above functions (MouseClick etc).

member.name: M:Au.Acc.VirtualClick
member.summary: Posts mouse-left-click message to the container window, using coordinates of this object.
member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, or the object is invisible/offscreen.
member.remarks: Does not move the mouse. Does not wait until the target application finishes processing the message. Works not with all objects. Use (try) this function when the object does not support . When both don't work, use MouseClick.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.VirtualRightClick
member.summary: Posts mouse-right-click message to the container window, using coordinates of this object.
member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, or the object is invisible/offscreen.
member.remarks: Does not move the mouse. Does not wait until the target application finishes processing the message. Works not with all objects. When does not work, use MouseClick.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.DoJavaAction(System.String)
member.summary: Performs one of actions supported by this Java accessible object.
member.param: Action name. See . If null (default), performs default action (like ) or posts Space key message. More info in Remarks.
member.remarks:
Read more about Java accessible objects in class help.
Problem: if the action opens a dialog, DoAction/DoJavaAction do not return until the dialog is closed (or fail after some time). The caller then waits and cannot automate the dialog. Also then this process cannot exit until the dialog is closed. If the action parameter is null and the object is focusable, this function tries a workaround: it makes the object (button etc) focused and posts Space key message, which should press the button; then this function does not wait.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.DoActionAndWaitForNewWebPage(System.Double,System.Action{Au.Acc})
member.summary: Calls or and waits until window name changes and web page name changes. Returns true. On timeout returns false if is negative; else exception.
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits indefinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, after that time interval returns false. Default 60 seconds.
If used, calls it instead of .
member.exception: Failed. For example, when this object is invalid, or its top-level window does not contain a web page.
The window was closed while waiting.
Exceptions thrown by or by the function.
member.remarks: This function is used to click a link in a web page and wait until current web page is gone. It prevents a following 'wait for object' function from finding a matching object in the old page, which would be bad. This function does not wait until the new page is completely loaded. There is no reliable/universal way for it. Instead, after calling it you can call a 'wait for object' function which waits for a known object that must be in the new page. This function cannot be used when the new page has the same title as current page. Then it waits until time or forever. The same if the action does not open a web page.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Select(Au.Types.AccSELFLAG)
member.summary: Selects or deselects.
member.param: Specifies whether to select, focus, add to selection etc. Can be two flags, for example AccSELFLAG.TAKEFOCUS | AccSELFLAG.TAKESELECTION.
member.exception: Failed to activate the window () or focus the control ().
member.remarks: Uses IAccessible.accSelect. Not all objects support it. Most objects support not all flags. It depends on object states FOCUSABLE, SELECTABLE, MULTISELECTABLE, EXTSELECTABLE, DISABLED. Many object have bugs, especially with flag TAKEFOCUS. More bugs when the object found with flag NotInProc.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Focus(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this object focused for keyboard input.
member.param: Add flag TAKESELECTION. Note: it is for selecting a list item, not for selecting text in a text box.
member.remarks: Calls with flag TAKEFOCUS and optionally TAKESELECTION. Not all objects support this action and not all work correctly. More info in Select documentation.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.SelectedChildren
member.summary: Gets selected direct child items. Returns empty array if there are no selected items of if failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.GetProperties(System.String,Au.Types.AccProperties@)
member.summary: Gets multiple properties.
member.param: Which properties to get. Each character specifies a property: 'R' - . 'n' - . 'v' - . 'd' - . 'h' - . 'a' - . 'k' - . 'u' - . 's' - . 'r' - . 'w' - . 'o' - outer. 'i' - inner. '@' - .
Receives results.
member.remarks:
The returned variable contains values of properties specified in . When a property is empty or failed to get, the member variable is "", empty dictionary or default value of that type; never null.
Normally this function is faster than calling multiple property functions, because it makes single remote procedure call. But not if this accessible object was found with flag etc.
Returns false if fails, for example when the object's window is closed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Navigate(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets an adjacent or related accessible object (AO) - next, child, parent, etc. Returns null if not found.
member.param:
String consisting of one or more navigation direction strings separated by space, like "parent next child4 first".
"next" - next sibling AO in the same parent AO.
"previous" - previous sibling AO in the same parent AO.
"first" - first child AO.
"last" - last child AO.
"parent" - parent (container) AO.
"child" - child AO by 1-based index. Example: "child3" (3-th child). Negative index means from end, for example -1 is the last child.
"#N" - N is a numeric value to pass to IAccessible.accNavigate as navDir. Can be any standard or custom value supported by the AO.
Can be only 2 letters, like "pr" for "previous". A string like "next3" or "next,3" is the same as "next next next". Except for "child".
For "next", "previous", "firstchild", "lastchild", "#N" is used IAccessible.accNavigate. Not all AOs support it. Some AOs skip invisible siblings. Instead you can use "parent childN" or "childN". For "parent" is used IAccessible.get_accParent. Few AOs don't support. Some AOs return a different parent than in the AO tree. For "child" is used API AccessibleChildren.
Wait for the wanted AO max this number of seconds. If negative, waits forever.

example.code: a = +a.Navigate("parent next ch3", true);

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Item(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Html(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets HTML.
member.param: If true, gets outer HTML (with tag and attributes), else inner HTML.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or if failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc. If this is the root of web page (role DOCUMENT or PANE), gets web page body HTML.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.HtmlAttribute(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a HTML attribute.
member.param: Attribute name, for example "href", "id", "class". Full, case-sensitive.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or does not have the specified attribute or failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.HtmlAttributes
member.summary: Gets all HTML attributes.
member.remarks: Returns empty dictionary if this is not a HTML element or does not have attributes or failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.ScrollTo
member.summary: Scrolls this accessible object into view.
member.exception: Failed to scroll, or the object does not support scrolling.
member.remarks:
This function works with these objects:
Web page objects in Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). With Find use role prefix "web:", "firefox:" or "chrome:", and don't use flag .
Objects in Edge browser, standard treeview and listview controls, some other. With Find use flag .

member.name: T:Au.Acc.Finder

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Find(Au.Wnd,System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.AFFlags,System.Func{Au.Acc,System.Boolean},System.Int32,Au.Wnd.ChildFinder)
member.summary: Finds accessible object (AO) in window. Returns the found AO. Returns null if not found. See examples.
member.param: Window or control that contains the AO.

AO role, like "LINK". Or path, like "ROLE/ROLE/ROLE". See . Can be used standard roles (see ) and custom roles (like "div" in Firefox). This parameter is string. If you want to use AccROLE: nameof(AccROLE.CHECKBOX). Case-sensitive, not wildcard. Use null to match any role. Cannot be "".
Role or path can have a prefix:
"web:" - search only in the visible web page, not in whole window. Examples: "web:LINK", "web:/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK". Supports Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer (IE) and apps that use their code. With other windows, searches in the first found visible AO that has DOCUMENT role. Chrome web page accessible objects normally are disabled (don't exist). Use prefix "web:" or "chrome:" to enable. Tip: To search only NOT in web pages, use "notin=DOCUMENT" (Chrome, Firefox) or "notin=PANE" (IE).
"firefox:" - search only in the visible web page of Firefox or Firefox-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Mozilla", can be used "web:" instead.
"chrome:" - search only in the visible web page of Chrome or Chrome-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Chrome", can be used "web:" instead.
Cannot use prefix when contains "id" or "class". Also with flag . Also when searching in Acc ().
Can be used path consisting of roles separated by "/". Examples:
"web:DOCUMENT/div/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK" - find LINK using its full path in web page.
"web:/div/LIST//LINK" - the empty parts mean 'any role'. For example don't need to specify DOCUMENT because in web pages the first part is always DOCUMENT (Firefox, Chrome) or PANE (IE).
"web:/div/LIST[4]/LISTITEM[-1]/LINK" - the 4 is 1-based index of div child from which to start searching (4-th, then 3-th, 5-th and so on). It can make faster. Negative means 'index from end', for example use -1 to search in reverse order. Flag is not applied to path parts with indexes. If index is invalid, will use the nearest valid index.
"web:/div/LIST[4!]/LISTITEM[-1!]/LINK" - like the above, but the LIST must be exactly 4-th child (don't search 3-th, 5-th etc) and the LISTITEM must be the last child. This can be useful when waiting (uses less CPU), however useless if AO indices in the window or web page change often.
"web://[4]/[-1!]/[2]" - index without role.
"CLIENT/WINDOW/TREE/TREEITEM[-1]" - path in window or control. The first path part is a direct child AO of the WINDOW AO of the window/control. The WINDOW AO itself is not included in the search; if you need it, instead use .
AO name (). String format: wildcard expression. null means 'any'. "" means 'empty or unavailable'.

Other AO properties and search settings. Format: one or more "name=value", separated with "\0" or "\0 ", like "description=xxx\0 @href=yyy". Names must match case. Values of string properties are wildcard expressions.
"class" - search only in child controls that have this class name (see ).
"id" - search only in child controls that have this id (see ).
"value" - .
"description" - .
"state" - . List of states that the AO must have and/or not have. Example: "state=CHECKED, FOCUSABLE, !DISABLED". Example: "state=0x100010, !0x1". Will find AO that has all states without "!" prefix and does not have any of states with "!" prefix.
"rect" - . Can be specified left, top, width and/or height, using format. Example: "rect={L=1155 T=1182 W=132 H=13}". Example: "rect={W=132 T=1182}". The L T coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
"level" - level (see ) at which the AO can be found. Can be exact level, or minimal and maximal level separated by space. The default value is 0 1000. Alternatively you can use path in role, like "////LINK".
"elem" - .
"action" - .
"key" - .
"help" - .
"uiaid" - .
"maxcc" - when searching, skip children of AO that have more than this number of direct children. It can make faster. The default value is 10000. It also prevents hanging or crashing when an AO in the object tree has large number of children. For example OpenOffice Calc TABLE has one billion children.
"notin" - when searching, skip children of AO that have these roles. It can make faster. Example: "notin=TREE,LIST,TOOLBAR". Roles in the list must be separated with "," or ", ". Case-sensitive, not wildcard. See also: .
"@attr" - . Here "attr" is any attribute name. Example: "@id=example".

Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching AO. Let it return true if this is the wanted AO. Example, the AO must contain point x y: o => o.GetRect(out var r, o.WndTopLevel) && r.Contains(266, 33)
0-based index of matching AO. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching AO and returns the second.

Properties of child controls where to search. This is an alternative for class/id in . Allows to specify more control properties. Works better/faster when the control is of a different process or thread than the parent window; else slightly slower.
member.exception: role is "" or invalid. name is invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression). prop has invalid format or contains unknown property names or invalid wildcard expressions. Using flag when searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc).
Failed. For example, window of a higher UAC integrity level process.
member.remarks: This function walks the tree of accessible objects of the window, control or web page, until it finds a matching AO. Uses . You can use it directly (see example). In wildcard expressions supports PCRE regular expressions (prefix "**r ") but not .NET regular expressions (prefix "**R "). They are similar. To find web page AOs usually it's better to use instead, it's more reliable. More info in class help.

member.summary: Gets or changes simple element id, also known as child id.
member.remarks: Most accessible objects (AO) are not simple elements. Then this property is 0. Often (but not always) this property is the 1-based item index in parent AO. For example LISTITEM in LIST. The 'set' function sometimes can be used as a fast alternative to . It modifies only this variable. It does not check whether the value is valid. Simple elements cannot have child AOs.

member.remarks: When Find or similar function finds an accessible object, it sets this property of the Acc variable. When searching in a window or control, at level 0 are direct children of the WINDOW object of the window or control. When searching in Acc, at level 0 are direct children of the Acc. When searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc), at level 0 is the web page object (role DOCUMENT or PANE).

member.name: M:Au.Acc.FromEvent(Au.Wnd,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the accessible object that generated the event that is currently being processed by the callback function used with API SetWinEventHook. Returns null if failed. Suports .
member.remarks: The parameters are of the callback function. Uses API AccessibleObjectFromEvent. Often fails because the object already does not exist, because the callback function is called asynchronously, especially when the event is OBJECT_DESTROY, OBJECT_HIDE, SYSTEM_*END. Returns null if failed. Always check the return value, to avoid NullReferenceException. An exception in a callback function used with API SetWinEventHook kills this process.

member.summary: This static instance is used by the static 'send keys' functions - , , and similar. See the second example.

member.name: P:Au.Input.SleepIn
member.summary: Wait milliseconds after sending each key down and up event. Default: 0. Valid values: 0 - 1000 (1 second).
member.remarks: If 0 (default), just sleeps briefly after some keys.

member.name: P:Au.Input.SleepAfter
member.summary: Wait milliseconds when all keys have been sent (before the function returns). Default: 50. Valid values: 0 - 5000 (5 seconds).

member.name: P:Au.Input._KeyFunc.Plus
member.summary: + operator. Presses the key and does not release. These keys are auto-released after next key or (keys) that is not followed by +. Also after next mouse click. Example: "Ctrl+Shift+A ...". Example: "Alt+(F O) ...". Example: "Ctrl+" ... Mouse.Click() //Ctrl auto-released here.

member.name: P:Au.Input._KeyFunc.Star
member.summary: * operator. 1. Repeats the preceding key. Example: "Tab*10" //press Tab 10 times. 2. Just presses (without releasing) or just releases. Example: "Ctrl*down" ... "Ctrl*up".

member.name: P:Au.Input._KeyFunc.ParenStart
member.summary: ( operator. 1. Encloses function arguments. Example: SLEEP(500). 2. Turns off auto-releasing keys pressed with operator +, until ")". Example: "Alt+(F O) ...". Example: "Ctrl+(" ... Mouse.Click(); Mouse.Click(); ... ")" //Ctrl released here.

member.name: P:Au.Input._KeyFunc.ParenEnd
member.summary: ) operator. Releases keys pressed with operator +, when auto-releasing was turned off with operator (. See .

member.name: T:Au.Input.Misc
member.summary: Less-often used functions related to keyboard input.

member.name: M:Au.Input.Misc.ReadKeyString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts keys string to Keys[] array.

member.name: M:Au.Input.Misc.ReadHotkeyString(System.String,System.Windows.Forms.Keys@)
member.summary: Converts hotkey string to Keys. For example, if s is "Ctrl+Left", hotkey will be Keys.Left with modifier flag Keys.Control. Must be single non-modifier key, preceded by zero or more of modifier keys Ctrl, Shift, Alt, Win, all joined with +. Named keys must match case. Keys A-Z don't have to match case. Valid hotkey examples: "A", "a", "7", "F12", ".", "End", "Ctrl+D", "Ctrl+Alt+Shift+Win+Left", " Ctrl + U ". Invalid hotkey examples: null, "", "A+B", "Ctrl+A+K", "A+Ctrl", "Ctrl+Shift", "Ctrl+", "NoSuchKey", "end". Returns false if the string is invalid.

member.name: M:Au.Input.Misc._KeyToModifier(System.Windows.Forms.Keys)
member.summary: If k is Shift, Control, Alt or Win (including left and right), returns it as modifier flag, eg Keys.Shift from Keys.ShiftKey. Else returns 0.

member.name: M:Au.Input.Misc._KeynameToKey(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to Keys. The string should contain single key name, eg "Esc", "A", "=". Returns 0 if invalid key name.

member.name: T:Au.WinImage
member.summary: Captures, finds and clicks images and colors in windows. An image is any visible rectangular part of window. A color is any visible pixel of window. A WinImage variable holds results of and similar functions (rectangle etc).

member.name: M:Au.WinImage.Capture(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Copies a rectangle of screen pixels to a new Bitmap object.
member.param: A rectangle in screen coordinates.
member.exception: Failed. Probably there is not enough memory for bitmap of this size (with*height*4 bytes).
member.remarks: PixelFormat is always Format32bppRgb.

member.name: M:Au.WinImage.Capture(Au.Wnd,Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Copies a rectangle of window client area pixels to a new Bitmap object.
member.param: Window or control.
A rectangle in w client area coordinates. Use w.ClientRect to get whole client area.
member.exception: Failed. Probably there is not enough memory for bitmap of this size (with*height*4 bytes).
member.remarks: How this is different from : 1. Gets pixels from window's device context (DC), not from screen DC, unless the Aero theme is turned off (on Windows 7). The window can be under other windows. 2. If the window is partially or completely transparent, gets non-transparent image. 3. Does not work with Windows Store app windows (creates black image) and possibly with some other windows. 4. If the window is DPI-scaled, captures its non-scaled view. And must contain non-scaled coordinates.

This function creates normal top-down bitmap, like new Bitmap(...), Bitmap.FromFile(...) etc do. 2. This function always creates bitmap of PixelFormat Format32bppRgb.

member.name: P:Au.WinImage.MatchIndex
member.summary: When there are multiple matching images, this is the 0-based index of current matching image. Can be used in callback function to create action "skip n matching images". Example: also: t => t.MatchIndex==1. When the image argument specifies multiple images, this will start from 0 for each image.

member.name: P:Au.WinImage.ListIndex
