member.name: M:Au.Mouse.Restore
member.summary: Moves the mouse cursor where it was at the time of the last call in this thread. If Save was not called - of the first 'mouse move' or 'mouse move and click' function call in this thread. Does nothing if these functions were not called.

member.name: P:Au.Mouse.LastMoveXY
member.summary: Mouse cursor position of the most recent successful 'mouse move' or 'mouse move and click' function call in this thread. If such functions are still not called in this thread, returns .

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.MoveRelative(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves the cursor (mouse pointer) relative to . Returns the final cursor position in primary screen coordinates.
member.param: X offset from LastMoveXY.X.
Y offset from LastMoveXY.Y.
member.exception: The calculated x y is not in screen. No exception if Options.Relaxed is true (then moves to a screen edge).

Failed to move to the calculated x y. Some reasons: 1. Another thread blocks or modifies mouse input (API BlockInput, mouse hooks, frequent API SendInput etc); 2. The active window belongs to a process of higher UAC integrity level; 3. Some application called API ClipCursor. No exception if Options.Relaxed is true (then final cursor position is undefined).
member.remarks: Uses Options.MouseMoveSpeed, Options.MouseClickSleep (sleeps Math.Min(Options.MouseClickSleep, 7)), Options.Relaxed.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.MoveRecorded(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Plays recorded mouse movements, relative to . Returns the final cursor position in primary screen coordinates.
member.param: String containing mouse movement data recorded by a recorder tool that uses .
Speed factor. For example, 0.5 makes 2 times faster.
member.exception: The string is not compatible with this library version (recorded with a newer version and has additional options).
The last x y is not in screen. No exception if Options.Relaxed is true (then moves to a screen edge).

Failed to move to the last x y. Some reasons: 1. Another thread blocks or modifies mouse input (API BlockInput, mouse hooks, frequent API SendInput etc); 2. The active window belongs to a process of higher UAC integrity level; 3. Some application called API ClipCursor. No exception if Options.Relaxed is true (then final cursor position is undefined).
member.remarks: Uses Options.MouseClickSleep (sleeps Math.Min(Options.MouseClickSleep, 7) after each movement, except if recorded with sleep times), Options.Relaxed (for the last movement; does not care about intermediate movements). Does not use Options.MouseMoveSpeed.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse._SendMove(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Sends single mouse movement event. x y are normal absolute coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse._SendButton(Au.Types.MButton,System.Boolean,System.Nullable{System.Drawing.Point})
member.summary: Sends single mouse button down or up event. Does not use the action flags of button. Applies SM_SWAPBUTTON. If pMoved!=null, also moves to pMoved in the same API SendInput call.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse._SendRaw(Au.Types.Api.IMFlag,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls Api.SendInput to send single mouse movement or/and button down or up or wheel event. Converts x, y and wheelTicks as need for MOUSEINPUT. For X buttons use Api.IMFlag.XDown|Api.IMFlag.X1 etc. If Api.IMFlag.Move, adds Api.IMFlag.Absolute.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse._SleepMax(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls Time.SleepDoEvents(). If ms is less than 0 or greater than Options.MouseClickSleep, uses Options.MouseClickSleep.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse._SleepExact(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls Time.SleepDoEvents().

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.ClickEx(Au.Types.MButton,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clicks, double-clicks, presses or releases a mouse button. By default does not move the mouse cursor.
member.param: Button and action. Default: left click.

Use . It is the mouse cursor position set by the most recent 'mouse move' or 'mouse move and click' function called in this thread. Use this option for reliability. Example: Mouse.Move(100, 100); Mouse.ClickEx(..., true);. The click is always at 100 100, even if somebody changes cursor position between Mouse.Move sets it and Mouse.ClickEx uses it. In such case this option atomically moves the cursor to LastMoveXY. This movement is instant and does not use Options.MouseMoveSpeed and Options.MouseClickSleep. If false (default), clicks at the current cursor position (does not move it).
member.exception: Invalid button flags (multiple buttons or actions specified).
member.remarks: The return value can be used to auto-release pressed button. See example with .

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.ClickEx(Au.Types.MButton,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.CoordOptions)
member.summary: Clicks, double-clicks, presses or releases a mouse button at position x y in screen. To move the mouse cursor, calls .
member.param: Button and action.
X coordinate relative to screen.
Y coordinate relative to screen.
Can be used to specify screen (see ) and/or whether x y are relative to the work area.
member.exception: Invalid button flags (multiple buttons or actions specified).

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.ClickEx(Au.Types.MButton,Au.Wnd,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean)

Window or control.
X coordinate relative to (but not limited to) the client area of w. Default - center.

The return value can be used to auto-release pressed button. See example with .

member.summary: Converts multiple recorded mouse movements to string for .

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1
member.summary: Like List or StringBuilder, used as a temporary variable-size array to create final fixed-size array. To avoid much garbage (and many reallocations when growing), uses native memory heap. See . Must be explicitly disposed to free the native memory. Does not have a finalizer because is struct (to avoid garbage). Does not support reference types. Does not call Dispose.

member.name: P:Au.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1.Ptr

member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of elements (not bytes) the internal memory can hold without resizing.
member.exception: (the 'set' function) value less than Count. Instead use ReAlloc or Free.

member.name: M:Au.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1.Alloc(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allocates count elements. Sets Count=count. Frees previously allocated memory. Returns memory address (address of element 0).
member.param: Element count.
Set all bytes = 0. If false, the memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Default true. Slower when true.

member.name: M:Au.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1.ReAlloc(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds or removes elements at the end. Sets Count=count. Preserves Math.Min(Count, count) existing elements. Returns memory address (address of element 0).
member.param: New element count.
Set all added bytes = 0. If false, the added memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Default true. Slower when true.
member.remarks: The new memory usually is at a new location. The preserved elements are copied there. Sets Count=count. To allocate more memory without changing Count, change Capacity instead.

member.summary: Frees memory. Sets Count and Capacity = 0.

member.name: T:Au.Util.StringCache
member.summary: Caches managed strings created from unmanaged char* buffers.
member.remarks: Can be used in possibly very frequently called functions to avoid much string garbage and frequent garbage collections. For example, Wnd.ClassName and Wnd.Name use this. They are called by Wnd.Find for each window (can be hundreds of them). And WaitFor.WindowExists calls Wnd.Find every 30 or so milliseconds. It could create megabytes of garbage (window classname and name strings) in a few seconds. Every Wnd.Find call creates almost the same set of strings, therefore it makes sense to cache them. To allow GC free the cached strings, use a WeakReferenc<StringCache> object. See example.

member.name: P:Au.Util.StringCache.Count

member.name: M:Au.Util.StringCache.Add(System.Char*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Searches in the cache for a managed string that matches unmanaged string p of length len. If finds, returns it. Else adds new string(p, 0, len) to the cache and returns it.
member.param: Unmanaged string.
p length.
member.remarks: speed when found in cache: similar to new string(p, 0, len).

p length.

member.name: M:Au.Util.SharedMemory.CreateOrGet(System.String,System.UInt32,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Creates named shared memory of specified size. Opens if already exists. Returns shared memory address in this process. Calls API CreateFileMapping and API MapViewOfFile.
member.param: Shared memory name. Case-insensitive.
Shared memory size. Ignored if the shared memory already exists.
Receives true if created and not opened.
member.remarks: Once the memory is created, it is alive at least until this process ends. Other processes can keep the memory alive even after that. There is no Close function to close the native shared memory object handle. The OS closes it when this process ends.

member.summary: Gets pointer to the shared memory.

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibProcessMemory
member.summary: Memory shared by all appdomains of current process. Size 0x10000 (64 KB). Initially zero.
member.remarks: When need to prevent simultaneous access of the memory by multiple threads, use lock("uniqueString"){...} . It locks in all appdomains, because literal strings are interned, ie shared by all appdomains. Using some other object with 'lock' would lock only in that appdomain. Maybe except Type. Use this only in single module, because ngened modules have own interned strings.

member.name: P:Au.Util.LibProcessMemory.Ptr
member.summary: Gets pointer to the memory.

member.name: F:Au.Util.LibProcessMemory.Size

member.name: T:Au.Util.NativeHeap
member.summary: Allocates memory from native heap of this process using heap API. Uses the common heap of this process, API GetProcessHeap. Usually slightly faster than Marshal class functions.

member.name: M:Au.Util.NativeHeap.Alloc(Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allocates new memory block and returns its address. Calls API HeapAlloc.
member.param: Byte count.
Set all bytes = 0. If false (default), the memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Slower when true.
member.exception: Failed. Probably size is too big.
member.remarks: The memory is unmanaged and will not be freed automatically. Always call when done or if need to resize it without losing data.

member.name: M:Au.Util.NativeHeap.ReAlloc(System.Void*,Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reallocates a memory block to make it bigger or smaller. Returns its address, which in most cases is different than the old memory block address. Preserves data in Math.Min(old size, new size) bytes of old memory (copies from old memory if need). Calls API HeapReAlloc or HeapAlloc.
member.param: Old memory address. If null, allocates new memory like Alloc.
New byte count.
When size is growing, set all added bytes = 0. If false (default), the added memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Slower when true.
member.exception: Failed. Probably size is too big.
member.remarks: The memory is unmanaged and will not be freed automatically. Always call when done or ReAlloc if need to resize it without losing data.

member.name: M:Au.Util.NativeHeap.Free(System.Void*)
member.summary: Frees a memory block. Does nothing if mem is null. Calls API HeapFree.

member.name: T:Au.Util.Buffers
member.summary: Allocates memory buffers that can be used with API functions and not only. Can allocate arrays of any value type - char[], byte[] etc.

member.name: M:Au.Util.Buffers.Get``1(System.Int32,System.WeakReference{``0[]}@)
member.summary: Allocates new or gets "cached" array of type T of length n or more. The returned array is managed by a WeakReference<T[]> variable provided by the caller. Its contents is undefined.
member.typeparam: Any value type, for example char, byte, RECT.
member.param: How many elements you need. If array in the WeakReference variable is null or too small, creates new array and stores it there. For byte[] and char[] types actually allocates Math.Max(n, 300)+1 elements. The 300 is to avoid future reallocations. The +1 can be used for example for '\0' character at the end of string.

A reference to a WeakReference variable that manages the returned array. If null, this function will create it. The variable should be [ThreadStatic] static. Or can be a non-static field of a long-living object. Must not be simply static, it's not thread-safe (unless locked).
member.remarks: Used to avoid creating much garbage when array allocations are needed frequently. Also is faster than code like var b=new byte[1000] or StringBuilder. The WeakReference variable allows the array to be garbage-collected if it is not used when GC runs. It is automatic and safe. Next time this function will create new array. Actually this function is a wrapper for WeakReference<T[]> functions TryGetTarget/SetTarget. Makes it easier to use.

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibStringBuilder
member.summary: Provides a cached reusable instance of StringBuilder per thread. It's an optimisation that reduces the number of instances constructed and collected. Used like using(new Au.Util.LibStringBuilder(out var b)) { b.Append("example"); var s = b.ToString(); }.
member.remarks: This is a modified copy of the .NET internal StringBuilderCache class. The cache uses 2 [ThreadLocal] StringBuilder instances, which allows 1 nesting level. Not error to use deeper nesting level, but then gets new StringBuilder, not from the cache.

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibEnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext
member.summary: Constructor ensures that current SynchronizationContext of this thread is WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext. Also sets WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.AutoInstall=false to prevent Application.DoEvents etc setting wrong context. Dispose() restores both if need. Does not restore context if was null. Example: using(new Util.LibEnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext()) { ... }

member.name: M:Au.Util.LibEnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: See class help.
member.param: Do nothing if WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.AutoInstall==false. Normally WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.AutoInstall is true (default).

member.name: M:Au.Util.LibEnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.EnsurePermanently
member.summary: If synchronization context of this thread is null or not WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext, makes it WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext. Use this instead of creating instance when will not need to restore previous synchronization context.
member.exception: This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null. Or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA
member.summary: Thread pool where COM can be used. Initializes thread COM as single-thread-apartment.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.WorkCallbackData
member.summary: Work callback function parameter type. More info: .

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.WorkCallback
member.summary: Work callback function type.
member.param: Contains state and completionCallback that were passed to the submit function. Your work callback function can change completionCallback and/or state. For example it can set completionCallback = null to prevent calling it (the call is expensive); or change state, if want to pass another object to the completion function. Note that the completion function is never called if initially it was null.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.SubmitCallback(System.Object,Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.WorkCallback,System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback)
member.summary: Requests that a thread pool thread call the callback function.
member.param: Something to pass to the callback functions.
Callback function to call in a thread pool thread.
Optional callback function to call in this thread after workCallback.
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.CreateWork(System.Object,Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.WorkCallback,System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback)
member.summary: Creates a object that can be used when need more options than SubmitCallback has.
member.param: Something to pass to the callback functions.
Callback function to call in a thread pool thread.
Optional callback function to call in this thread after workCallback.
member.remarks: Call Dispose() to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this appdomain ends.
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work
member.summary: Allows to submit a callback function (one or more times) to be called in thread pool threads, then optionally wait and cancel. Can be used when need more options than SubmitCallback has.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.#ctor(System.Object,Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.WorkCallback,System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback,System.Boolean)
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Submit
member.summary: Requests that a thread pool thread call the callback function. This function can be called multiple times.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Wait
member.summary: Waits until all submitted instances of the callback function finish their work. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Cancel
member.summary: Waits until all running instances of the callback function finish their work, and cancels pending (still not running) instances. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Dispose
member.summary: Calls , releases all resources used by this object and allows this object to be garbage-collected. Call this to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this appdomain ends.

member.summary: Gets small icon size that depends on DPI of the primary screen. Width and Height are /6, which is 16 if DPI is 96 (100%).

member.summary: Wraps a waitable timer handle. Allows to create, open, set and wait. More info: API CreateWaitableTimer. Note: will need to dispose.

member.name: M:Au.Util.WaitableTimer.Create(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Calls API CreateWaitableTimer and creates a WaitableTimer object that wraps the timer handle.
member.param: Timer name. If a timer with this name already exists, opens it if possible. If null, creates unnamed timer.
member.exception: Failed. For example, a non-timer kernel object with this name already exists.

member.name: M:Au.Util.WaitableTimer.Open(System.String,System.UInt32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calls API OpenWaitableTimer and creates a WaitableTimer object that wraps the timer handle.
member.param: Timer name. Fails if it does not exist; to open-or-create use .
.See Synchronization Object Security and Access Rights. The default value TIMER_MODIFY_STATE|SYNCHRONIZE allows to set and wait.
member.exception: Failed. For example, a non-timer kernel object with this name already exists.
member.param: If fails, return null, don't throw exception. Supports .
member.exception: Failed. For example, the timer does not exist.

member.name: M:Au.Util.WaitableTimer.Set(System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API SetWaitableTimer. Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.param: The time after which the state of the timer is to be set to signaled. It is relative time (from now). If positive, in milliseconds. If negative, in 100 nanosecond intervals (microseconds*10), see FILETIME. Also can be 0, to set minimal time.
The period of the timer, in milliseconds. If 0, the timer is signaled once. If greater than 0, the timer is periodic.

member.name: M:Au.Util.WaitableTimer.SetAbsolute(System.DateTime,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API SetWaitableTimer. Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.param: The UTC date/time at which the state of the timer is to be set to signaled.
The period of the timer, in milliseconds. If 0, the timer is signaled once. If greater than 0, the timer is periodic.

member.name: M:Au.Util.LibWorkarounds.WaitCursorWhenShowingMenuEtc
member.summary: A workaround for: When showing a ContextMenuStrip menu or a submenu, something briefly sets the AppStarting cursor. Only if this process does/did not have active windows. Only if current cursor is arrow. Works well if eg I or hand. Starts before first WM_NCPAINT (after WM_SHOWWINDOW+WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING) and stops before WM_PAINT. Call this before showing a menu. Possibly also will need for some other windows.

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibActCtx
member.summary: Activates our manifest which tells to use comctl32.dll version 6. The manifest is embedded in this dll, resource id 2. This code is from .NET MessageBox.Show.

member.summary: Writes array, List, Dictionary or other generic collection to the output, as a list of item values.
member.param: Array or generic collection of any type. Can be null.

Item format string.
These special substrings are replaced with: {0} - item index, starting from 0. {1} - item index, starting from 1. {2} - item string value, or empty string if null. {3} - item string value, or "null" if null. Strings are escaped () and enclosed in "".
If this parameter is null or omitted, uses "{3}\r\n". It works like .
How many characters to remove from the end of the result string. Default 2 (removes the default "\r\n" separator from the last item).
member.remarks: Calls and .

Text before . Default "Warning: ".

member.summary: Converts binary data stored in byte[] to hex-encoded string.

Let the hex string contain A-F, not a-f.

data memory size (bytes).

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.HexDecode(System.String)
member.summary: Converts hex-encoded string to binary data. Stores it in byte[].
member.param: Hex-encoded string. Can be null, then returns null.
member.remarks: Skips spaces and other non-hex-digit characters. Example: "01 23 46 67" is the same as "01234667". The number of hex-digit characters should be divisible by 2, else the last character is ignored.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.HexDecode(System.String,System.Void*,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts hex-encoded string to binary data. Stores it in caller's memory buffer. Returns the number of bytes stored in resultBuffer memory. It is equal or less than Math.Min(bufferSize, (s.Length - stringStartIndex) / 2).
member.param: Hex-encoded string. Can be null.
Where to write the data. Can be any valid memory of specified size, for example a struct address.
resultBuffer memory size. Note: this function will damage process memory if using bad resultBuffer or bufferSize.
0 or index of first character of hex-encoded substring in s.
member.remarks: Skips spaces and other non-hex-digit characters. Example: "01 23 46 67" is the same as "01234667". The number of hex-digit characters should be divisible by 2, else the last character is ignored.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.HexDecode(System.Char*,System.Int32,System.Void*,System.Int32)
member.summary: The same as but the string can be an unmanaged UTF-16 string.
member.param: UTF-16 string.
s length (characters).

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Base64Decode(System.Byte*,System.Int32,System.Void*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts Base64 ANSI string to binary data (bytes). Stores it in caller's memory buffer. Returns the number of bytes stored in resultBuffer.
member.param: Base64 string. Can be null if len is 0.
s length (bytes).
A memory buffer for the result bytes. Must be of at least bufferSize size, else this function will damage process memory.
resultBuffer buffer length (bytes). Must be at least (int)(len * 3L / 4), else exception.
member.remarks: Allows (discards) non-base64 characters. Supports URL-safe characters: '-' for '+' and '_' for '/'.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Base64Decode(System.Char*,System.Int32,System.Void*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts Base64 UTF-16 string to binary data (bytes). Stores it in caller's memory buffer. Returns the number of bytes stored in resultBuffer.
member.param: Base64 string. Can be null if len is 0.
s length (characters).
A memory buffer for the result bytes. Must be of at least bufferSize size, else this function will damage process memory.
resultBuffer buffer size (bytes). Must be at least (int)(len * 3L / 4), else exception.
member.remarks: How it is different than Convert.FromBase64String: 1. Allows (discards) non-base64 characters. 2. Supports URL-safe characters: '-' for '+' and '_' for '/'. 3. No exception when string length is not multiple of 4, eg if does not contain '=' characters for padding. 4. Faster.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Base64Decode(System.String,System.Void*,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts Base64 UTF-16 string to binary data (bytes). Stores it in caller's memory buffer. Returns the number of bytes stored in resultBuffer. The same as , just different input string type.
member.param: Base64 string. Can be null, then returns null.
A memory buffer for the result bytes. Must be of at least bufferSize size, else this function will damage process memory.
resultBuffer buffer size (bytes). Must be at least (int)(len * 3L / 4), else exception.
0 or index of first character of Base64 substring in s.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Base64Decode(System.String)
member.summary: Converts Base64 string to binary data (bytes). Returns byte[] containing the data.
member.param: Base64 string. Can be null, then returns null.
member.remarks:
How it is different than Convert.FromBase64String: 1. Allows (discards) non-base64 characters. 2. Supports URL-safe characters: '-' for '+' and '_' for '/'. 3. No exception when string length is not multiple of 4, eg if does not contain '=' characters for padding. 4. Faster.
This library does not have Base64-encode functions. Use . See also . It does the same, but does not support some parameter types (char*, ANSI string, byte* buffer) that are used internally in this libray and related software, that is why these library functions were created.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8FromString(System.String,System.Byte*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts C# string to '\0'-terminated UTF8 string. Stores the UTF8 string in caller's buffer. Returns UTF8 string length in bytes, not including the terminating '\0' character. If fails (unlikely if passed correct arguments), returns 0 and sets buffer="".
member.param: C# string (UTF16). Can be null.
Caller-allocated memory of bufLen length.
buffer length in bytes. Should be at least +1, else converts only part of string. The maximal possible required buffer length for whole string can be s.Length*3+1.
member.remarks: Calls API WideCharToMultiByte. This is the most low-level and therefore fastest overload. Does not allocate any memory. With big strings much faster than .NET Encoding class functions. Use buffer/bufLen carefully. If bufLen is greater that the memory buffer length, other memory will be overwritten/damaged.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8FromString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts C# string to '\0'-terminated UTF8 string.
member.param: C# string (UTF16). If null, returns null.
member.remarks: How this is different from .NET Encoding class functions: 1. Uses WideCharToMultiByte. 2. Faster with big strings. 3. The returned string is '\0'-terminated. 4. No exceptions (unless the string is so large that fails to allocate so much memory).

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.LibUtf8FromString(System.String,System.WeakReference{System.Byte[]}@,System.Int32*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts C# string to '\0'-terminated UTF8 string managed by a WeakReference variable.
member.param: C# string (UTF16). If null, returns null, unless allocExtraBytes is not 0.
A WeakReference variable (probably [ThreadStatic]) that manages the returned array. If null, this function will create it.
If not null, receives UTF8 text length, not including '\0' and allocExtraBytes.
Allocate this number of extra bytes after the string.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8ToStringLength(System.Byte*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the number of characters that would by produced by converting UTF8 to C# string. The terminating '\0' character is not included in the return value.
member.param: UTF8 string. Can be null.
Length of utf8 or part of it. If negative, the function finds utf8 length; then utf8 must be '\0'-terminated.
member.remarks: Uses API MultiByteToWideChar. There is no overload that takes byte[], because for it can be used .NET Encoding class functions.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8ToString(System.Byte*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts UTF8 string to C# string (which is UTF16). The terminating '\0' character is not included in the returned string.
member.param: UTF8 string. If null, returns null.
Length of utf8 or part of it. If negative, the function finds utf8 length; then utf8 must be '\0'-terminated.
member.remarks: Uses API MultiByteToWideChar. There is no overload that takes byte[], because for it can be used .NET Encoding class functions. The speed is similar; this is slower with short strings but faster with long strings.

member.name: T:Au.Debug_
member.summary: Functions useful to debug code.
member.remarks: The Debug_.PrintX functions write to the same output as , not to the trace listeners like etc do. Also they add caller's name, file and line number. Functions Print, PrintIf, PrintFunc and Dialog work only if DEBUG is defined, which normally is when the caller project is in Debug configuration. Else they are not called, and arguments not evaluated at run time. This is because they have [("DEBUG")]. Note: when used in a library, the above functions depend on DEBUG of the library project and not on DEBUG of the consumer project of the library. For example, the library may be in Release configuration even if its consumer project is in Debug configuration. If your library wants to show some info only if its consumer project is in Debug config, instead you can use code like if(Options.Debug) PrintWarning("text");; see , .

member.name: P:Au.Debug_.TextPrefix
member.summary: Prefix for Debug_.Print, Debug_.PrintIf, Debug_.PrintHex. Default is "Debug: ".
member.example:
Blue text.
Debug_.TextPrefix = "<><c 0xff0000>"; Debug_.TextSuffix = "</c>";

member.name: P:Au.Debug_.TextSuffix
member.summary: Suffix for Debug_.Print, Debug_.PrintIf, Debug_.PrintHex.

member.name: M:Au.Debug_.Print(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Calls to show some debug info. Also shows current function name/file/line. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional parameters are not used explicitly.

member.name: M:Au.Debug_.PrintIf(System.Boolean,System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If condition is true, calls to show some debug info. Also shows current function name/file/line. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional parameters are not used explicitly.

member.name: M:Au.Debug_.PrintHex(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Calls to show some integer value in hex format. Also shows current function name/file/line. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional parameters are not used explicitly.

member.name: M:Au.Debug_.PrintFunc(System.String)
member.summary: Calls with current function name. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The optional parameter is not used explicitly.

member.name: M:Au.Debug_.Dialog(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Calls to show some debug info. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional parameters are not used explicitly.

member.name: M:Au.Debug_.LibCheckFlagsOpt``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Checks flags and throws ArgumentException if some flags are invalid. The message includes valid flag names. Can be used in functions that have an enum flags parameter but not all passed flags are valid for that function or object state. Does nothing if Options.Debug is false.
member.param: Flags to check.
Valid flags.
member.typeparam: The enum type used for flags.
member.remarks: When flags are valid, this function is very fast (inline, no calls).

member.summary: Returns true if using Debug configuration of Au.dll.

member.name: T:Au.Output
member.summary: Writes text to the output window, console or log file.

member.name: P:Au.Output.IsConsoleProcess

member.name: P:Au.Output.IsWritingToConsole
member.summary: Returns true if is writing to console, false if to the output window or log file. Assuming that is not changed. Does not write to console in these cases: is false. is true. is not null. The startup info of this process tells to not show console window and to not redirect the standard output.

member.name: P:Au.Output.IgnoreConsole
member.summary: If true, Write and related functions in console process don't not use the console window. Then everything is like in non-console process.

member.name: M:Au.Output.Clear
member.summary: Clears the output window or console text (if ) or log file (if not null).

member.name: M:Au.Output.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Writes string + "\r\n" to the output window or console (if ) or log file (if not null).

member.name: P:Au.Output.Writer
member.summary: Gets or sets object that actually writes text when is called Output.Write, Print and similar functions.
member.remarks: If you want to redirect, modify or just monitor output text, use code like in the example. It is known as "output redirection". Redirection is applied to whole appdomain, and does not affect other appdomains. Redirection affects Output.Write, Print and similar functions, also Output.RedirectConsoleOutput and Output.RedirectDebugOutput. It does not affect Output.WriteDirectly and Output.Clear. Don't call Output.Write, Print etc in method WriteLine(string) of your writer class. It would call itself and create stack overflow. But you can call Output.WriteDirectly.

member.name: T:Au.Output._OutputWriter
member.summary: Our default writer class for the Writer property.

member.name: M:Au.Output.WriteDirectly(System.String)
member.summary: Writes string value + "\r\n" to the output window or console (if ) or log file (if not null). Unlike Output.Write, Print etc, the string is not passed to .

member.name: P:Au.Output.RedirectConsoleOutput
member.summary: Let Console.WriteX methods in non-console process write to the same destination as Output.Write etc.
member.remarks: Console.Write will write line, like Console.WriteLine. Console.Clear will not clear output; it will throw exception.

member.name: P:Au.Output.RedirectDebugOutput
member.summary: Let Debug.WriteX and Trace.WriteX methods write to the same destination as Output.Write etc.
member.remarks: Tip: To write to the output window even in console process, set Output.IgnoreConsole=true; before calling this method first time.

member.name: P:Au.Output.LogFile
member.summary: Sets log file path. When set (not null), text passed to Output.Write, Print and similar functions will be written to the file. Assuming that is not changed. If value is null - restores default behavior.
member.remarks:
The first Write etc call (in this appdomain) creates or opens the file and deletes old content if the file already exists. Multiple appdomains cannot use the same file. If the file is open for writing, Write makes unique filename and changes LogFile value.
Also supports mailslots. For LogFile use mailslot name, as documented in CreateMailslot. Multiple appdomains and processes can use the same mailslot.
member.exception: The 'set' function throws this exception if the value is not full path and not null.

member.name: P:Au.Output.LogFileTimestamp
member.summary: Let Write etc also add current time when using log file (see ). The time is local, not UTC.

member.name: P:Au.Output.LibWriteToQM2
member.summary: Sets to use QM2 as the output server. Eg can be used to debug the Output class itself. Although can instead use console.

member.name: M:Au.Output._WriteToQM2(System.String)
member.param: If null, clears output.

member.name: M:Au.Output._CreateFile(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calls Api.CreateFile to open file or mailslot.
member.param: File path or mailslot name.
Use OPEN_EXISTING. If false, uses CREATE_ALWAYS.

member.name: M:Au.Output._LogFile.Open
member.summary: Opens LogFile file handle for writing. Uses CREATE_ALWAYS, GENERIC_WRITE, FILE_SHARE_READ.
member.remarks: Multiple appdomains cannot use the same file. Each appdomain overwrites it when opens first time.

member.name: M:Au.Output._LogFile.WriteLine(System.String)
member.summary: Writes s + "\r\n" and optionally timestamp.
member.remarks: If fails to write to file: Sets LogFile=null, which closes file handle. Writes a warning and s to the output window or console.

member.name: M:Au.Output._LogFile.Clear
member.summary: Sets file size = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Output._LogFile.Close
member.summary: Closes file handle.

member.name: T:Au.Output.Server
member.summary: Receives messages sent from clients when they call Output.Write and related methods. If server is global, clients can be multiple appdomains and processes, including this. Else only this appdomain.
member.remarks:
Works asynchronously, to make writing messages faster. When a client writes a message, the message arrives to the server with some delay and is placed in the queue. You then can get/remove messages (call Messages.TryDequeue) and display them in a window (for example). You can be notified about new messages.
Recommended setup (see example): 1. When your application starts, create an Output.Server instance and assign to a static variable. Call Start. 2. When your application creates its output window, call to register callback function. 3. In the callback function get/remove/display all new messages. 4. Call Stop when closing the window. Optional but recommended.

member.name: T:Au.Output.Server.MessageType
member.summary: See .

member.name: F:Au.Output.Server.MessageType.Write
member.summary: Add line to the output window. All Message members can be used.

member.name: F:Au.Output.Server.MessageType.Clear
member.summary: Clear the output window. Other Message members are not used.

member.name: T:Au.Output.Server.Message

member.summary: Sets callback function, to be notified about server events.

A control or form. The callback function will be called in its thread (). If null, the callback function will be called in other thread.

member.summary: Opens window's process handle. This overload is more powerful: if API OpenProcess fails, it tries GetProcessHandleFromHwnd, which can open higher integrity level processes, but only if current process is uiAccess and desiredAccess includes only PROCESS_DUP_HANDLE, PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, PROCESS_VM_READ, PROCESS_VM_WRITE, SYNCHRONIZE. Returns null if fails. Supports Native.GetError().
member.param: Desired access (Api.PROCESS_), as documented in MSDN -> OpenProcess.

member.name: M:Au.Process_.Memory.SetMem(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets an address of memory in that process that is to be used by the read and write functions.
member.param: A memory address in that process.

Let the Dispose method (or finalizer) call API VirtualFreeEx to free mem. The memory must be allocated with API VirtualAllocEx (by any process) or VirtualAlloc (by that process). If false, mem can be any memory in that process, and this variable will not free it. Alternatively you can use and .
member.exception: This variable already has Mem, unless it was set by this function with = false.
member.remarks: This function can be used if this variable was created with nBytes = 0. Else exception. Also exception if this function previously called with = true.

member.exception: Failed to open process handle (usually because of UAC) or allocate memory.

member.summary: Copies a string from this process to the memory allocated in that process by the constructor. In that process the string is written as '\0'-terminated UTF-16 string. For it is used (s.Length+1)*2 bytes of memory in that process (+1 for the '\0', *2 because UTF-16 character size is 2 bytes). Returns false if fails.

Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.

Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
If null, uses system's default ANSI encoding.

member.summary: Copies a string from the memory in that process allocated by the constructor to this process. Returns the copied string, or null if fails. In that process the string must be in Unicode UTF-16 format (ie not ANSI).
member.param: Number of characters to copy. In both processes a character is 2 bytes.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
Find true string length by searching for '\0' character in nChars range. If false, the returned string is of nChars length even if contains '\0' characters.

Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
Find true string length by searching for '\0' character in nBytes range of the ANSI string.
If null, uses system's default ANSI encoding.

member.name: T:Au.Process_.UacInfo
member.summary: Holds access token (security info) of a process and provides various security info, eg UAC integrity level.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.UnsafeTokenHandle
member.summary: Access token handle.
member.remarks: The handle is managed by this variable and will be closed when disposing or GC-collecting it. Use where need.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.Failed
member.summary: Gets true if the last called property function failed. Normally getting properties should never fail. Only the GetOfProcess method can fail, then it returns null.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.Elevation
member.summary: Gets process UAC elevation type. Elevation types: Full - runs as administrator (High or System integrity level). Limited - runs as standard user (Medium, Medium+UIAccess or Low integrity level) on administrator user session. Default - all processes in this user session run as admin, or all as standard user. Can be: non-administrator user session; service session; UAC is turned off. Unknown - failed to get. Normally it never happens; only GetOfProcess can fail, then it returns null. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IsUIAccess
member.summary: Returns true if the process has uiAccess property. A uiAccess process can access/automate all windows of processes running in the same user session. Most processes don't have this property and cannot access/automate windows of higher integrity level (High, System, Middle+uiAccess) processes and Windows 8 store apps. For example, cannot send keys and Windows messages. Note: High IL (admin) processes also can have this property, therefore IsUIAccess is not the same as IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess==IL.UIAccess (IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess returns IL.UIAccess only for Medium+uiAccess processes; for High+uiAccess processes it returns IL.High). Some Windows API work slightly differently with uiAccess and non-uiAccess admin processes. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevel
member.summary: Gets process UAC integrity level (IL). IL from lowest to highest value: Untrusted - the most limited rights. Very rare. Low - very limited rights. Used by Internet Explorer tab processes, Windows Store apps. Medium - limited rights. Most processes (unless UAC turned off). UIAccess - Medium IL + can access/automate High IL windows (user interface). Note: Only the property can return UIAccess. This property returns High instead (the same as in Process Explorer). High - most rights. Processes that run as administrator. System - almost all rights. Services, some system processes. Protected - undocumented. Never seen. Unknown - failed to get IL. Never seen. The IL enum member values can be used like if(x.IntegrityLevel > IL.Medium) ... . If UAC is turned off, most non-service processes on administrator account have High IL; on non-administrator - Medium.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess
member.summary: The same as IntegrityLevel, but can return UIAccess.

member.name: M:Au.Process_.UacInfo.GetOfProcess(System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens process access token and creates UacInfo object that holds it. Returns UacInfo object. Then you can use its properties. Returns null if failed. For example fails for services and some other processes if current process is not administrator. To get UacInfo of this process, instead use UacInfo.ThisProcess.
member.param: Process id. If you have a window, use its ProcessId property.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.ThisProcess
member.summary: Gets UacInfo object of current process.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IsAdmin
member.summary: Returns true if current process is running as administrator, ie if the user belongs to the local Administrators group and the process is not limited by UAC. This function for example can be used to check whether you can write to protected locations in the file system and registry.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IsUacDisabled
member.summary: Returns true if UAC is disabled (turned off) on this Windows 7 computer. On Windows 8 and 10 UAC cannot be disabled, although you can disable UAC elevation consent dialogs.

Uses task dialog API TaskDialogIndirect.
Cannot be used in services. Instead use with option ServiceNotification or DefaultDesktopOnly, or API MessageBox with corresponding flags.

member.name: P:Au.AuDialog.Result
member.summary: Gets selected button id and other results packed in a DResult variable. It is the same variable as the ShowDialog return value. If the result is still unavailable (eg the dialog still not closed): If called from the same thread that called ShowDialog, returns null. If called from another thread, waits until the dialog is closed and the return value is available. Note that ShowDialogNoWait calls ShowDialog in another thread.

member.name: M:Au.AuDialog.ThreadWaitForOpen
member.summary: Can be used by other threads to wait until the dialog is open. If returns true, the dialog is open and you can send messages to it. If returns false, the dialog is already closed or failed to show.

member.name: M:Au.AuDialog.ThreadWaitForClosed
member.summary: Can be used by other threads to wait until the dialog is closed.

member.name: P:Au.AuDialog.Send
member.summary: Allows to modify dialog controls while it is open, and close the dialog. Example: d.Send.Close(); . Example: d.Send.ChangeText2("new text", false); . Example: d.Send.Message(TDApi.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); .
member.remarks: Can be used only while the dialog is open. Before showing the dialog returns null. After closing the dialog the returned variable is deactivated; its method calls are ignored. Can be used in dialog event handlers. Also can be used in another thread, for example with ShowNoWaitEx and ShowProgressEx.

member.name: T:Au.AuDialog.TDMessageSender

member.summary: Sends a message to the dialog. Call this method while the dialog is open, eg in an event handler. Example (in an event handler): e.dialog.Send.Message(TDApi.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); Also there are several other functions to send some messages: change text, close dialog, enable/disable buttons, set progress. Reference: task dialog messages. NAVIGATE_PAGE currently not supported.

Title bar text. If omitted, null or "", uses .

If not 0, auto-close the dialog after this time (seconds) and set result's Button property = .
member.remarks: The returned DResult variable has these properties: selected button id, selected radio button id, check box state. Tip: DResult supports implicit cast to int. You can use code switch(AuDialog.ShowEx(...)) instead of switch(AuDialog.ShowEx(...).Button) . Tip: For optional parameters use named arguments. Example: AuDialog.ShowEx("Text.", icon: DIcon.Info, title: "Title") . This function allows you to use most of the dialog features, but not all. Alternatively you can create a AuDialog class instance, set properties and call ShowDialog. Example in class help.

member.name: M:Au.AuDialog.Show(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.DIcon,Au.Types.DFlags,Au.Types.DOwner,System.String)
member.summary: Shows dialog. Returns selected button id.
member.param: Main instruction. Bigger font.
Text below main instruction.

Button ids and labels, like "1 OK|2 Cancel|5 Save|4 Don't Save". Missing ids are auto-generated, for example "OK|Cancel|100 Custom1|Custom2" is the same as "1 OK|2 Cancel|100 Custom1|101 Custom2". The first in the list button is default, ie responds to the Enter key. For example, "2 No|1 Yes" adds Yes and No buttons and makes No default. Trims newlines around ids and labels. For example, "
1 One
|
2
Two

" is the same as "1 One|2 Two".
To create keyboard shortcuts, use & character in custom button labels. Use && for literal &. Example: "1 &Tuesday[]2 T&hursday[]3 Saturday && Sunday".
There are 6 common buttons: OK, Yes, No, Retry, Cancel, Close. Buttons that have other labels are custom buttons. How common buttons are different: 1. DFlags.CommandLinks does not change their style. 2. They have keyboard shortcuts that cannot be changed. Inserting & in a label makes it a custom button. 3. Button Cancel can be selected with the Esc key. It also adds X (Close) button in title bar, which selects Cancel. 4. Always displayed in standard order (eg Yes No, never No Yes). But you can for example use "2 No|1 Yes" to set default button = No. 5. The displayed button label is localized, ie different when the Windows UI language is not English.
If omitted, null or "", the dialog will have OK button, id 1. You can use in flags to change the style of custom buttons. See also: .
Owner window or null. See .
Text that the user can show and hide.
member.remarks: Calls . Tip: For optional parameters use named arguments. Example: AuDialog.Show("Text.", icon: DIcon.Info) .

member.name: T:Au.CsvTable
member.summary: Parses and composes CSV text. Stores CSV table data in memory as a List of string arrays. CSV is a text format used to store a single table of data in human-readable/editable way. It is a list of lines (called rows or records) containing one or more values (called fields or cells) separated by a separator character. There is no strictly defined CSV standard. CsvTable uses these rules: Fields containg characters (default ','), characters (default '"') and multiple lines must be enclosed in characters. Example: "ab, cd". Each Quote character in such fields must be escaped (replaced) with two characters. Example: "ab ""cd"" ef". Fields that start or end with ASCII space or tab characters must be enclosed in characters, unless is false. Example: " ab ". Rows in CSV text can have different field count.

member.name: M:Au.CsvTable.#ctor(System.String)

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.Data
member.summary: Gets the internal List containing rows as string arrays. It's not a copy; changing it will change the data of this CsvTable variable. You can do anything with the List. For example, sort it, find rows containing certain field values, get/set field values directly, add/remove rows directly. All row arrays have Length equal to , and it must remain so; you can change Length, but then need to call ColumnCount=newLength.

example.code: x.Data.Sort((a,b) => string.CompareOrdinal(a[0], b[0]));

member.name: T:Au.Time
member.summary: Time functions. Get, wait, doevents, timer, precision.

member.name: P:Au.Time.Microseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of microseconds elapsed since Windows startup. The precision is 1 microsecond.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. Includes the computer sleep/hibernate time (see also ). Independent of computer clock time changes. MSDN article: Acquiring high-resolution time stamps.

member.name: P:Au.Time.Milliseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup. The precision is 1 millisecond. See also .
member.remarks: Includes the computer sleep/hibernate time (see also ). Independent of computer clock time changes. Unlike Environment.TickCount, this function is more precise and returns a 64-bit value that will not roll over in 100 years.

member.name: P:Au.Time.MillisecondsWithoutComputerSleepTime
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup, not including time the system spends in sleep or hibernation. The precision is 1-16 milliseconds.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryUnbiasedInterruptTime. Independent of computer clock time changes. This function can be used to implement a timeout in 'wait for' functions, when repeatedly checking a condition.

member.name: M:Au.Time.WaitS(System.Double)
member.summary: Suspends this thread for the specified amount of time. The same as , but uses seconds, not milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, seconds. The smallest value is 0.001 (1 ms).
member.exception: seconds is less than 0 or greater than 2147483 (int.MaxValue/1000, 24.8 days).
member.remarks: Calls . Does not process events and messages, therefore should not be used in threads with windows, timers or COM events. Supports asynchronous procedure calls. If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is seconds + the sleep/hibernate time. Tip: code 5.s(); is the same as Time.WaitS(5);.

member.name: M:Au.Time.Sleep(System.Int32)
member.summary: Suspends this thread for the specified amount of time. The same as , but uses milliseconds, not seconds; and supports Timeout.Infinite.
member.param: Time to wait, milliseconds. If 0, can wait briefly if another busy thread runs on the same logical CPU, which happens not often on modern multi-core CPU. Also can be .
member.remarks: Calls . Does not process events and messages, therefore should not be used with big milliseconds in threads with windows, timers or COM events. Supports asynchronous procedure calls. If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is milliseconds + the sleep/hibernate time. Tip: code 50.ms(); is the same as Time.Sleep(50);.
member.exception: milliseconds is negative and not Timeout.Infinite.

member.name: M:Au.Time.SleepDoEvents(System.Int32)
member.summary: Partially suspends this thread for the specified amount of time, during which processes events and messages.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait. The smallest value is 1. Also can be .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function retrieves and dispatches all Windows messages, including posted (key/mouse input, window paint, timer and other). Also calls event handlers, hook procedures, etc. Supports asynchronous procedure calls. This function can be used in threads with windows. However usually there are better ways, for example timer, other thread, async/await/Task. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as . In some places does not work as expected, for example in Form/Control mouse event handlers .NET blocks other mouse events. In threads without windows and timers usually don't need to process posted messages, but in some cases need to process sent messages, some events, hooks etc. Then you can instead use , like Thread.CurrentThread.Join(1000);. Calls API MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx and .
member.exception: milliseconds is negative and not Timeout.Infinite.
Any exceptions thrown by functions that are executed while waiting (event handlers etc).

member.name: M:Au.Time.DoEvents
member.summary: Retrieves and dispatches messages from the message queue of current thread.
member.remarks: If this thread has a .NET message loop (), calls . Else uses more lightweight API functions PeekMessage, TranslateMessage and DispatchMessage. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as .
member.exception: Any exceptions thrown by functions that are executed while dispatching messages (event handlers etc).

member.name: M:Au.Time.s(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls . Example: 5.s(); is the same as Time.WaitS(5);.

member.name: M:Au.Time.s(System.Double)
member.summary: Calls . Example: 2.5.s(); is the same as Time.WaitS(2.5);.

member.name: M:Au.Time.ms(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls . Example: 50.ms(); is the same as Time.Sleep(50);.

member.name: T:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision
member.summary: Temporarily changes the time resolution/precision of Thread.Sleep and some other functions.
member.remarks: Uses API timeBeginPeriod, which requests a time resolution for various system timers and wait functions. Actually it is the system thread scheduling timer period. Normal resolution on Windows 7-10 is 15.625 ms. It means that, for example, Thread.Sleep(1); sleeps not 1 but 1-15 ms. If you set resolution 1, it sleeps 1-2 ms. The new resolution is revoked (timeEndPeriod) when disposing the LibSleepPrecision variable or when this process ends. See example. See also . The resolution is applied to all threads and processes. Other applications can change it too. For example, often web browsers temporarily set resolution 1 ms when opening a web page. The system uses the smallest period (best resolution) that currently is set by any application. You cannot make it bigger than current value. It is not recommended to keep small period (high resolution) for a long time. It can be bad for power saving. Don't need this for Time.Sleep, Time.WaitS, Time.SleepDoEvents and functions that use them (Mouse.Click etc). They call when the sleep time is 1-99 ms. This does not change the minimal period of and System.Windows.Forms.Timer.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API timeBeginPeriod.
member.param: New system timer period, milliseconds. Should be 1. Other values may stuck and later cannot be made smaller due to bugs in OS or some applications; this bug would impact many functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.Dispose
member.summary: Calls API timeEndPeriod.

member.name: P:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.Current
member.summary: Gets current actual system time resolution (period). The return value usually is between 0.5 and 15.625 milliseconds. Returns 0 if fails.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.TempSet1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Temporarily sets the system wait precision to 1 ms. It will be revoked after the specified time or when this appdomain ends. If already set, just updates the revoking time.
member.param: Revoke after this time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.LibTempSet1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls TempSetMax if sleepTimeMS is 1-99.
member.param: milliseconds of the caller 'sleep' function.

member.name: T:Au.WaitFor
member.summary: Contains functions to wait for a condition, such as 'window exists'.
member.remarks:
All functions have a secondsTimeout parameter. It is the maximal time to wait, seconds. If it is 0, waits indefinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, after that time interval stops waiting and returns default value (false, default(Wnd), etc).
While waiting, messages and events are not processed. For example, if used in a Form/Control event handler, the form would stop responding. Then need to use another thread, for example async/await/Task, like in the example.

member.name: T:Au.WaitFor.LibTimeout
member.summary: Can be used to easily implement timeout in wait-for functions. See how it is used eg in .

member.name: P:Au.WaitFor.LibTimeout.Period
member.summary: Current period, milliseconds. Initially it is constructor->initPeriod (default 10). The Sleep method increments it until reached MaxPeriod.

member.name: P:Au.WaitFor.LibTimeout.MaxPeriod
member.summary: Maximal period, milliseconds. It is constructor->maxPeriod (default 500).

member.name: P:Au.WaitFor.LibTimeout.TimeRemaining
member.summary: Remaining time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.LibTimeout.IsTimeout
member.summary: If the timeout is not expired, returns false. Else if constructor->secondsTimeout was negative, returns true. Else throws TimeoutException. Also gets current time and updates private fields, if need.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.LibTimeout.Sleep
member.summary: If IsTimeout(), returns false. Else sleeps for Period milliseconds, increments Period if it is less than MaxPeriod, and returns true.

Callback function (eg lambda). It is called repeatedly, until returns true.
Something to pass to the callback function.
The initial period of calling the callback function, in milliseconds.

The maximal period of calling the callback function, in milliseconds. The period is incremented by 1 millisecond in each loop until it reaches maxPeriod. It gives a good response time initially, and small CPU usage after some time.

Hidden and minimized windows also can be active. This function by default waits until the window is active and visible. To ignore visibility, use flag . To wait until the window also is not minimized, use the 'also' parameter, like in the example.
More examples: see .

example.code: Wnd w = WaitFor.WindowActive(60, "*- Notepad", also: t => !t.IsMinimized); Print(w);

member.name: T:Au.Wnd
member.summary: A variable of Wnd type represents a window or control. It is a window handle, also known as HWND. Wnd functions can be used with windows and controls of any process/thread. Wnd functions also can be used with .NET form/control and WPF window class variables, like Wnd w=(Wnd)form; w.Method(...); or ((Wnd)form).Method(...);.
member.remarks:
There are two main types of windows - top-level windows and controls. Controls are child windows of top-level windows.
More functions are in the nested classes - , etc. They are used mostly in programming, rarely in automation scripts.
What happens when a Wnd function fails:
Functions that get window properties don't throw exceptions. They return false/0/null/empty. Most of them support , and it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions that change window properties throw exception. Exceptions are listed in function documentation. Almost all these functions throw only .
Other functions that change window properties return false. They are more often used in programming than in automation scripts.
When a 'find' function does not find the window or control, it returns default(Wnd) (window handle 0). Then will return true.
If a function does not follow these rules, it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions fail if the window's process has a higher UAC integrity level (aministrator, uiAccess) than this process, unless this process has uiAccess level. Especially the functions that change window properties. Some functions that still work: Activate, ActivateLL, ShowMinimized, ShowNotMinimized, ShowNotMinMax, Close.
The Wnd type can be used with native Windows API functions without casting. Use Wnd for the parameter type in the declaration, like [DllImport(...)] static extern bool NativeFunction(Wnd hWnd, ...).
See also: MSDN article Window Features.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.op_Explicit(System.Windows.Forms.Control)~Au.Wnd

member.summary: Posts a message to the message queue of the specified thread. Calls API PostThreadMessage. Returns its return value (false if failed). Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WaitForAnActiveWindow
member.summary: Waits while there is no active window. It sometimes happens after closing, minimizing or switching the active window, briefly until another window becomes active. Waits max 500 ms, then returns false if there is no active window. Processes Windows messages that are in the message queue of this thread. Don't need to call this after calling functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.EnableActivate
member.summary: Temporarily enables this process to activate windows with API SetForegroundWindow. Returns false if fails (unlikely). In some cases you may need this function because Windows often disables SetForegroundWindow to not allow applications to activate their windows while the user is working (using keyboard/mouse) with the currently active window. Then SetForegroundWindow just makes the window's taskbar button flash which indicates that the windows wants attention. More info: SetForegroundWindow. Usually you don't call SetForegroundWindow directly. It is called by some other functions, for example Form.Show. Don't need to call this function before calling Wnd.Activate and other functions of this library that activate windows.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.TaskbarButton

member.summary: Starts or stops flashing the taskbar button.

The number of times to flash. If 0, stops flashing.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.TaskbarButton.ProgressState

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames
member.summary: Gets programming names of .NET Windows Forms controls. Usually each control has a unique name. It is useful to identify controls without a classic name/text. Control id of these controls is not constant and cannot be used.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.#ctor(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Prepares to get control names.
member.param: Any top-level or child window of that process.
member.exception: Failed to allocate process memory (see ) needed to get control names, usually because of UAC.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.GetControlName(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets control name. Returns null if fails or the name is empty.
member.param: The control. Can be a top-level window too. Must be of the same process as the window specified in the constructor.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.IsWinFormsControl(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if window class name starts with "WindowsForms". Usually it means that we can get Windows Forms control name of w and its child controls.
member.param: The window. Can be top-level or control.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.GetSingleControlName(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets the programming name of a Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails.
member.param: The control. Can be top-level window too.
member.remarks: This function is easy to use and does not throw excaptions. However, when you need names of multiple controls of a single window, better create a WinFormsControlNames instance (once) and for each control call its GetControlNameOrText method, it will be faster.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow
member.summary: Creates window and allows your derived class to replace its window procedure. Similar to , but more lightweight and does not change the class name. Can register a new window class or extend (subclass) an existing class.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.Handle
member.summary: Native window handle.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.Create(System.String,System.String,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.Wnd,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Creates window. Calls API CreateWindowEx. Returns false if failed, for example className is not registered.
member.param: The name of any window class existing in this process. You can register a class with or use any other class.
Window name or null.
One or more Native.WS_ constants, like Native.WS_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW|Native.WS_VISIBLE.
One or more Native.WS_EX_ constants.
Owner or parent window, or default.
Control id or 0.
member.remarks: Your derived class should override , which calls the window procedure of window class . The window will be destroyed in these cases: 1. Called . 2. Closed by the user or some program/script. 3. When this thread ends. 4. This function called again (then destroys old window and creates new).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.CreateMessageWindow(System.String)
member.summary: Creates message-only window. Styles: WS_POPUP, WS_EX_NOACTIVATE. More info: .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.Destroy
member.summary: Destroys the window. Calls API DestroyWindow. Does nothing if the window is already destroyed, for example closed by the user. If the window is not destroyed explicitly, the system destroys it when its thread ends.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.WndProc(Au.Wnd,System.UInt32,Au.Types.LPARAM,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Calls the window procedure of the window class (see ) and manages the lifetime of this variable. Your derived class should override this function. Your WndProc must call it (base.WndProc) and return its return value, except when don't need default processing. Always call it on WM_NCCREATE and WM_NCDESTROY. More info: Window Procedures.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.RegisterClass(System.String,Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.WndClassEx)
member.summary: Registers new window class. Returns class atom.
member.param: Class name.

Can be used to specify more fields of WNDCLASSEX that is passed to RegisterClassEx. Defaults: hCursor = arrow; hbrBackground = COLOR_BTNFACE+1; style = CS_GLOBALCLASS; others = 0/null/default. This function also adds CS_GLOBALCLASS style.
member.exception: Failed, for example if the class already exists and was registered not with this function.
member.remarks: Calls API RegisterClassEx. The class then can be used in all appdomains of this process. To create windows, use . Each class derived from MyWindow provides its own window procedure (overrides ). Windows created not with use API DefWindowProc as window procedure, and therefore are not useful. The window class remains registered until this process ends. Don't need to unregister. This function can be called multiple times for the same class, for example called once in each appdomain. Next time it just returns class atom. Thread-safe. Don't use code like static ushort _atom = Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.RegisterClass("MyClass");, because in Release configuration compiler removes this code if _atom is not used. Instead you can call this function in a static constructor.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.WndClassEx
member.summary: Used with .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.AllWindows(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows. Returns array containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd.
member.param: Need only visible windows.
Place all array elements of hidden windows at the end of the array, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API EnumWindows. The list can be bigger than you expect, because there are many invisible windows, tooltips, etc. See also MainWindows. By default array elements are sorted to match the Z order. On Windows 8 and later gets only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess; to get such windows you can use FindFast.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.ThreadWindows(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows of a thread. Returns array containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd.
member.param: Unmanaged thread id. See , . If 0, throws exception. If other invalid value (ended thread?), returns empty list. Supports .
Need only visible windows.
Place all array elements of hidden windows at the end of the array, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API EnumThreadWindows.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.FindMessageWindow(System.String,System.String,Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Finds a message-only window and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. Calls API FindWindowEx. Faster than Find, which does not find message-only windows. Can be used only when you know full name and/or class name. Finds hidden windows too.
member.param: Name. Use null to match any. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
Class name. Use null to match any. Cannot be "". Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
If used, starts searching from the next window in the Z order.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.WndActiveOfThisThread
member.summary: Gets the active window of this thread. Calls API GetActiveWindow.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.WndTop
member.summary: Gets the very first top-level window in the Z order. Usually it is a topmost window. Calls API GetTopWindow(default(Wnd)).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.WndRoot
member.summary: Gets the virtual parent window of all top-level windows. Calls API GetDesktopWindow. It is not the visible desktop window (see ).

member.summary: Gets a window of the shell process (usually process "explorer", class name "Progman"). Calls API GetShellWindow. In most cases it is not the window that contains desktop icons (see ). But it belongs to the same thread.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.WndDesktop
member.summary: Gets the desktop window. It displays desktop icons and wallpaper in its child control . The "Show Desktop" command (Win+D) activates it. It is not the same as API GetDesktopWindow (see ). This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.WndDesktopControl
member.summary: Gets the control of "SysListView32" class that contains desktop icons and wallpaper. It is a child of . This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.IsMainWindow(Au.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)

Return false if w is minimized.

member.summary: Gets main windows, ie those that probably are in the Windows taskbar. Returns array containing 0 or more Wnd.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WndNextMain(Au.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets next window in the Z order, skipping invisible and other windows that probably are not in the Windows taskbar. Returns default(Wnd) if there are no such windows.
member.param: Start from this window. If default(Wnd), starts from the top of the Z order.
On Windows 10 include windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps (only if this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess).
Skip minimized windows.
If w is not default(Wnd) and there are no matching windows after it, retry from the top of the Z order. Then can return w.
member.remarks: Uses . This function is quite slow. Does not match the order of buttons in the Windows taskbar.

member.remarks: Character '&' is used to underline next character in displayed text of dialog controls and menu items. Two '&' are used to display single '&'. The underline is displayed when using the keyboard (eg Alt key) to select dialog controls and menu items.
