member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Is0
member.summary: Returns true if the handle is 0.

example.code: Wnd w = Wnd.Find("Window*"); if(w.Is0) { Print("window not found"); return; }

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsAlive
member.summary: Returns true if the handle identifies an existing window. Returns false if the handle is 0 or invalid. Invalid non-0 handle usually means that the window is closed/destroyed.
member.remarks: Calls and API IsWindow. Although a Wnd variable holds a window handle, which is like a reference to a window, it does not prevent closing that window and making the handle invalid. After closing the window, the OS can even assign the same handle value to a new window, although normally it can happen only after long time. Use this carefully with windows of other applications or threads. The window can be closed at any moment, even when your thread is still in this function.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsVisible
member.summary: Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks:
Calls API IsWindowVisible. Does not call .
Even when this function returns true, the window may be actually invisible. It can be cloaked, on an inactive Windows 10 virtual desktop (cloaked), inactive Windows Store app (cloaked), transparent, zero-size, minimized, off-screen, covered by other windows or can have zero-size window region.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsVisibleEx
member.summary: Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks:
Returns false if API IsWindowVisible returns false. Also returns false if returns true, but only for some popup windows that usually are useless and could cause problems if considered visible. Else returns true.
Even when this function returns true, the window may be actually invisible. It can be cloaked (excepth the above case), on an inactive Windows 10 virtual desktop (cloaked), inactive Windows Store app (cloaked), transparent, zero-size, minimized, off-screen, covered by other windows or can have zero-size window region.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsVisibleAndNotCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if returns true and returns false.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Show(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use ShowLL.
member.remarks: Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ShowLL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder.
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Show and ShowLL. Show is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. ShowLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. ShowLL is more low-level. Does not throw exception when fails, and does not add a delay; Show adds a small delay when the window is of other thread.
Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsEnabled
member.summary: Gets the enabled state. Returns true if the window is enabled. Returns false if is disabled or is a child of disabled parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsWindowEnabled.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Enable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the window. Calls API EnableWindow.
member.param: Enable or disable.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsCloakedGetState
member.summary: Gets the cloaked state. Returns 0 if not cloaked or if failed. Else returns flags: 1 cloaked by its application, 2 cloaked by Windows, 4 cloaked because its owner window is cloaked. On Windows 7 returns 0 because there is no "cloaked window" feature.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if the window is cloaked. Returns false if not cloaked or if failed. On Windows 7 returns false because there is no "cloaked window" feature. Windows 10 uses window cloaking mostly to hide windows on inactive desktops. Windows 8 - mostly to hide Metro app windows.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsMinimized
member.summary: Returns true if minimized, false if not. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsIconic.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsMaximized
member.summary: Returns true if maximized, false if not. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsZoomed.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ShowMinimized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If not minimized, minimizes. Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ShowMaximized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If not minimized, minimizes. Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ShowNotMinMax(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If maximized or minimized, makes normal (not min/max). Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ShowNotMinimized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If minimized, restores previous non-minimized state (maximized or normal). Also unhides.
member.param: Visually fast, without animation.
member.exception: The API call failed. No exception if the window did not obey.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd._MinMaxRes(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets window min/max/normal/restore state. Also unhides.
member.param: Must be SW_MINIMIZE, SW_RESTORE (restores to normal/max if minimized), SW_SHOWNORMAL or SW_SHOWMAXIMIZED.
Use SetWindowPlacement (no animation).

member.exception: Failed. Throws, only if errStr!=null, else returns false.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Lib
member.summary: Internal static functions.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib.EnableActivate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: No exceptions.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib._EnableActivate_SendKey(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a key (VK_0 up). It allows to activate now. Later this process can always activate easily (without key etc). It works even with higher IL windows. Don't know why is this behavior. Tested on all OS from XP to 10. Does not work if the foreground process has higher UAC IL.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib._EnableActivate_MinRes
member.summary: Creates a temporary minimized window and restores it. It activates the window and allows us to activate. Then sets 'no active window' to prevent auto-activating another window when destroying the temporary window.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib._EnableActivate_AllowSetFore
member.summary: Calls Api.AllowSetForegroundWindow(Api.GetCurrentProcessId()).

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.NoThrowIfInvalid
member.summary: Don't call ThrowIfInvalid at the very start (ie called ensures it is valid).

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.NoGetWndWindow
member.summary: Don't call WndWindow (ie caller ensures it's a top-level window, not control).

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.IgnoreIfNoActivateStyleEtc
member.summary: Don't activate if has WS_EX_NOACTIVATE style or is toolwindow without caption, unless cloaked. Then just calls ZorderTop(), which in most cases does not work (inactive window).

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.ForScreenCapture
member.summary: Wait for window animations to end. Eg when switching Win10 desktops.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib.MoveInScreen(System.Boolean,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.Wnd,Au.Types.RECT@,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Used directly by MoveInScreen, EnsureInScreen, RECT.MoveInScreen, RECT.EnsureInScreen.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Lib.WinFlags
member.summary: Calls API SetProp/GetProp to set/get window flags .

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Lib.EnumCallback
member.summary: For EnumWindows2.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib.EnumWindows2(Au.Wnd.Lib.EnumWindowsAPI,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Au.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Int32,Au.Wnd.Lib.EnumCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: This version creates much less garbage (the garbage would be the returned managed array). The caller must dispose the returned LibArrayBuilder.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.LibActivate(Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags)
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). The same as , but has some options. Returns false if does not activate because of flag IgnoreIfNoActivateStyleEtc.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Activate
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). Also unhides, restores minimized etc, to ensure that the window is ready to receive sent keys, mouse clicks ect.
member.remarks:
Activating a window usually also uncloaks it, for example switches to its virtual desktop on Windows 10. Fails (throws exception) if cannot activate this window, except:
If this is a control, activates its top-level parent window.
If this is , just deactivates the currently active window.
When the target application instead activates another window of the same thread.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ActivateLL
member.summary: Low-level version of . Just calls , API SetForegroundWindow and makes sure that it actually worked, but does not check whether it activated exactly this window. No exceptions, does not unhide, does not restore minimized, does not check is it a top-level window or control, etc. Returns false if fails.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Focus
member.summary: Sets the keyboard input focus to this control or window. Also activetes its top-level parent window (see ). Can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function .
member.remarks: Can instead focus a child control. For example, if this is a ComboBox, it will focus its child Edit control. Then does not throw exception.
member.exception: Invalid handle; disabled; failed to set focus; failed to activate parent window. Fails to set focus when the target process is admin and this process isn't.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndFocused
member.summary: Gets the control or window that has the keyboard input focus. It can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls API GetGUIThreadInfo.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsFocused
member.summary: Returns true if this is the control or window that has the keyboard input focus. Can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FocusLocal
member.summary: Calls API SetFocus, which sets the keyboard input focus to this control or window, which must be of this thread. Fails if it belongs to another thread or is invalid or disabled. Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.remarks: Can instead focus a child control. For example, if this is a ComboBox, it will focus its child Edit control. Then returns true.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndFocusedLocal
member.summary: Gets the control or window of this thread that has the keyboard input focus. Calls API GetFocus.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsFocusedLocal
member.summary: Returns true if this is the control or window of this thread that has the keyboard input focus. Calls API GetFocus.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Moves and resizes.
member.remarks:
See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max, does not support SWP_ flags. This function is low-level, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags SWP_NOZORDER|SWP_NOOWNERZORDER|SWP_NOACTIVATE|swpFlagsToAdd. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves.
member.remarks:
See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max. This function is low-level, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags SWP_NOSIZE|SWP_NOZORDER|SWP_NOOWNERZORDER|SWP_NOACTIVATE. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ResizeLL(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Resizes.
member.remarks: See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max. This function is low-level, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags SWP_NOMOVE|SWP_NOZORDER|SWP_NOOWNERZORDER|SWP_NOACTIVATE. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Move(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.CoordOptions)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .
member.param: Left. If null, does not move in X axis.
Top. If null, does not move in Y axis.
Width. If null, does not change width.
Height. If null, does not change height.
Allows to specify screen (see ) and/or whether to use the work area. Not used when this is a child window. For width/height used when width or height is Coord.Reverse etc.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Move(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.CoordOptions)
member.summary: Moves. Calls Move(x, y, null, null, workArea). With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .
member.param: Left. If null, does not move in X axis.
Top. If null, does not move in Y axis.
Allows to specify screen (see ) and/or whether to use the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Resize(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.CoordOptions)
member.summary: Resizes. Calls Move(null, null, width, height, workArea). With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .
member.param: Width. If null, does not change width.
Height. If null, does not change height.
Allows to specify screen (see ) and/or whether to use the work area. Used when width or height is Coord.Reverse etc. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveInScreen(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window to coordinates x y in specified screen, and ensures that entire window is in screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen. If null - screen center. You also can use Coord.Reverse etc.
Y coordinate in the specified screen. If null - screen center. You also can use Coord.Reverse etc.
Move to this screen (see ). If null (default), use screen of this window.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
If part of window is not in screen, move and/or resize it so that entire window would be in screen. Default true.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately, except when moving maximized to another screen.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.EnsureInScreen(System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window if need, to ensure that entire window is in screen.
member.param: Move to this screen (see ). If null (default), uses screen of this window. If screen index is invalid, shows warning, no exception. Then uses screen of this window.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveToScreenCenter(System.Object)
member.summary: Moves this window to the center of the screen. Calls ShowNotMinMax(true) and MoveInScreen(null, null, screen, true, true).
member.param: Move to this screen (see ). If null (default), uses screen of this window.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Screen
member.summary: Gets object of the screen that contains this window (the biggest part of it) or is nearest to it. If this window handle is default(Wnd) or invalid, gets the primary screen. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderAbove(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Places this window before window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is default(Wnd), calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderBelow(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Places this window after window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is default(Wnd), calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderTop
member.summary: Places this window or control at the top of the Z order. If the window was topmost, it will be at the top of topmost windows, else at the top of non-topmost windows (after topmost windows). Does not activate. In most cases does not work with top-level inactive windows, although returns true; instead use .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderBottom
member.summary: Places this window or control at the bottom of the Z order. If the window was topmost, makes it and its owner window non-topmost.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderTopmost
member.summary: Makes this window topmost (always on top of non-topmost windows in the Z order). Does not activate. If this window has an owner window, the owner does not become topmost. This cannot be a control.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderNoTopmost(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this window non-topmost. If this window has an owner window, makes the owner window non-topmost too. This cannot be a control.
member.param: Also place this window after the active nontopmost window in the Z order, unless the active window is its owner.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsTopmost
member.summary: Returns true if this is a topmost (always-on-top) window.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderIsBefore(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if this window is above window w in the Z order.

If is true, calls API GetWindowThreadProcessId, OpenProcess and IsWow64Process. If you know that the window belongs to current process, instead use or IntPtr.Size==8. This function is much slower.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Name
member.summary: Gets window or control name. Returns "" if no name. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: It is not the .NET Control.Name property. To get it you can use . Top-level window name usually its title bar text. Control name usually is its text that does not change, for example button or static (label) control text. Unlike , this function usually does not get variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. Calls (false, true).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ControlText
member.summary: Gets control text. Returns "" if no text. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function prefers variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. For controls that cannot have such text (eg button, static), it usually gets the same text as Name. For example button and static (label) controls. Much slower than Name. Fails if the window is hung. Calls (true, false).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetText(System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets window/control name or control text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports . This is a low-level function. You can instead use and .
member.param: false - use API function InternalGetWindowText. It is fast and usually does not get variable text. This is used by . true - use API message WM_GETTEXT. It is slow and prefers variable text. This is used by . Fails if the window is hung. null - try InternalGetWindowText. If it gets "", and this is a control, then try WM_GETTEXT.
Remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key. Removes only if this is a control (has style Native.WS_CHILD). Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd._GetTextFast(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Calls API InternalGetWindowText. If it fails, and getControlTextIfEmpty==true, and this is a control, calls _GetTextSlow, which uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd._GetTextSlow
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.SetText(System.String)
member.summary: Sets window/control name or control text.
member.param: Text. Can be null, it is the same as "".
member.remarks: Uses API WM_SETTEXT. Top-level window name usually its title bar text. For variable-text controls (edit, combo box, status bar, ...) this usually is the text that would get. For other controls (button, static, ...) and top-level windows this usually is the text that would get.
member.exception: Failed, for example the window is closed.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.NameWinForms
member.summary: Gets Control.Name property of a .NET Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails. Use this with controls of other processes. Don't use with your controls, when you have a Control object. This is slow when getting names of multiple controls in a window. Instead create a instance and call its method for each control.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ProcessName
member.summary: Gets filename (without ".exe") of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and Process_.GetProcessName.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ProcessPath
member.summary: Gets full path of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and Process_.GetProcessName.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Close(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes the window. Returns true if successfuly closed or if it was already closed (the handle is 0 or invalid) or if noWait==true.
member.param: If false (default), waits a while until the window is destroyed or disabled. But does not wait indefinitely. If true, does not wait.

If false (default), uses API message WM_CLOSE. If true, uses API message WM_SYSCOMMAND SC_CLOSE, like when the user clicks the X button in the title bar. Most windows can be closed with any of these messages, but some respond properly only to one of them. For example, some applications on WM_CLOSE don't exit, although the main window is closed. Some applications don't respond to WM_SYSCOMMAND if it is posted soon after opening the window, for example Internet Explorer.
member.remarks: The window may refuse to be closed. For example, it may be hung, or hide itself instead, or display a "Save?" message box, or is a dialog without X button, or just need more time to close it. If the window is of this thread, just calls Send (if noWait==false) or Post (if noWait==true) and returns true.

example.code: //close all Notepad windows Wnd.FindAll("* Notepad", "Notepad").ForEach(t => t.Close());

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Child(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds a child control and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See also: , , .
member.param:
Control name. By default the function gets control names with . Can start with these prefix strings:
"**text:" - use . It is slower and can be less reliable (because can get editable text), especially if className not used. It does not remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key.
"**accName:" - use . Useful when the control itself does not have a name but an adjacent Static text control is used as its name. Examples - Edit controls in dialogs. Slower.
"**wfName:" - use .NET Windows Forms Control Name property. To get it this function uses . It is slower and can fail because of UAC.
"**id:" (like "**id:15") - use control id. To get it this function uses . Cannot be wildcard expression. You can instead use , it is faster than Child.
String format (not including the prefix): wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. "" means 'must not have name'.
Control class name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "".
Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching control. It can evaluate more properties of the control and return true when they match. Example: also: t => t.IsEnabled
0-based index of matching control. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching control and returns the second.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
className is "". To match any, use null. Invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MenuClick(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Posts a "menu item clicked" notification (WM_COMMAND) as if that menu item was clicked. Does not use the mouse.
member.param: Menu item id. Must be in range 1 to 0xffff.
The menu item is in the title bar's context menu, not in the menu bar. Posts WM_SYSCOMMAND instead.
member.remarks: Works only with standard (classic) menus. The drop-down menu window class name must be "#32768". Works with menu items in window menu bar, system menu and some context menus. Does not use the menu itself. Just posts WM_COMMAND or WM_SYSCOMMAND message. Even if a menu item with this id does not exist. This variable is the window that contains the menu bar or system menu. Or the drop-down menu window (class "#32768") that contains the menu item.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FromXY(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.WXYFlags,Au.Types.CoordOptions)
member.summary: Gets visible top-level window or control from point. By default the coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
member.param: X coordinate in screen.
Y coordinate in screen.
Can be used to specify screen (see ) and/or whether x y are relative to the work area.
member.remarks: Alternatively can be used API WindowFromPoint, ChildWindowFromPointEx or RealChildWindowFromPoint, but all they have various limitations and are not very useful in automation scripts. This function gets non-transparent controls that are behind (in the Z order) transparent controls (group button, tab control etc); supports more control types than RealChildWindowFromPoint. Also does not skip disabled controls. All this is not true with flag Raw. This function is not very fast. Fastest when used flag NeedWindow. Flag Raw also makes it faster. x and y can be Coord.Reverse etc; cannot be null.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd._WindowsStoreAppFrameChild(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: On Win10+, if w is "ApplicationFrameWindow", returns the real app window "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" hosted by w. If w is minimized, cloaked (eg on other desktop) or the app is starting, the "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" is not its child. Then searches for a top-level window named like w. It is unreliable, but MS does not provide API for this. Info: "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" windows hosted by "ApplicationFrameWindow" belong to separate processes. All "ApplicationFrameWindow" windows belong to a single process.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Find(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object)
member.summary: Finds a top-level window and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See also: , , . See examples.
member.param: Window name. Usually it is the title bar text. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. "" means 'must not have name'.
Window class name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "".

Program file name without ".exe". String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "". Cannot be path.
Or a list of the following properties. Format: one or more "name=value", separated with "\0" or "\0 ". Names must match case. Values of string properties are wildcard expressions.
"program" - program file name. Example: "program=notepad". Useful when need multiple properties or when file name contains character '='.
"pid" - process id. See , . Example: $"pid={pidVar}".
"tid" - thread id. See , . Example: "tid=" + tidVar.
"owner" - owner window handle. See . Example: $"owner={w1.Handle}".
Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching window. It can evaluate more properties of the window and return true when they match. Example: also: t => !t.IsPopupWindow.

Text, image or other object in the client area of the window. Depends on type: string - name of an accessible object () that must be in the window. Wildcard expression, the same as the name parameter of . - arguments for . Defines an accessible object that must be in the window. - arguments for . Defines a child control that must be in the window. or - image that must be visible in the window. To find it, this function calls with flag . See also .
This parameter is evaluated after .
member.remarks: If there are multiple matching windows, gets the first in the Z order matching window, preferring visible windows. On Windows 8 and later finds only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has uiAccess; to find such windows you can use FindFast. To find message-only windows use instead.
member.exception: className is "". To match any, use null. programEtc is "" or contains an empty/0 value or unknown property. To match any, use null. Invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.LastFind
member.summary: Gets arguments and result of this thread's last call to or .
member.remarks: WaitFor.WindowActive and similar functions don't change this property. and some other functions of this library change this property because they call internally.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FindAll(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object)
member.summary: Finds all matching windows. Returns array containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd. Everything except the return type is the same as with .
member.remarks: The list is sorted to match the Z order, however hidden windows (when using WFFlags.HiddenToo) are always after visible windows.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FindFast(System.String,System.String,Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Finds a top-level window and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. To check it you can use or . Calls API FindWindowEx. Faster than Find, which uses API EnumWindows. Can be used only when you know full name and/or class name. Finds hidden windows too.
member.param: Name. Use null to match any. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
Class name. Use null to match any. Cannot be "". Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
If used, starts searching from the next window in the Z order.
member.remarks: To find message-only windows use instead. Supports . It is not recommended to use this function in a loop to enumerate windows. It would be unreliable because window positions in the Z order can be changed while enumerating. Also then it would be slower than Find and FindAll.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FindOrRun(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object,System.Func{System.Int32},System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds a top-level window. If found, activates (optionally), else calls callback function that should open the window (eg call ) and waits for the window. Returns window handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found (if runWaitTimeoutS is negative; else exception). The first 5 parameters are the same as .
member.param: Callback function's delegate. See example.
How long to wait for the window after calling the callback function. Seconds. Default 60. See .
Finally the window must be active. For more info see the algorithm in Remarks.

example.code: Wnd w = Wnd.FindOrRun("* Notepad", run: () => Shell.Run("notepad.exe")); Print(w);

member.name: T:Au.Wnd._WndList
member.summary: An enumerable list of Wnd for and . Holds Util.LibArrayBuilder or IEnumerator or single Wnd or none. Must be disposed if it is Util.LibArrayBuilder or IEnumerator, else disposing is optional.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndOwner
member.summary: Gets or sets the owner window of this top-level window.
member.remarks: A window that has an owner window is always on top of its owner window. Don't call this for controls, they don't have an owner window. The 'get' function returns default(Wnd) if this window isn't owned or is invalid. Supports . The 'set' function can fail, eg if the owner's process has higher UAC integrity level.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndWindow
member.summary: Gets the top-level parent window of this control. If this is a top-level window, returns this. Returns default(Wnd) if this window is invalid.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsChildWindow
member.summary: Returns true if this is a child window (control), false if top-level window.
member.remarks: Supports . Uses . Another way is w.HasStyle(Native.WS_CHILD). It is faster but less reliable, because some top-level windows have WS_CHILD style and some child windows don't.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.IsChildOf(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if this is a direct or indirect child (descendant) of window w. Calls API IsChild.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndDirectParent
member.summary: Gets the window or control that is the direct parent of this control. Returns default(Wnd) if this is a top-level window. If you need the top-level parent window, use instead.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndDirectParentOrOwner
member.summary: Gets the window or control that is the direct parent of this control or owner of this top-level window. Calls API GetParent. Faster than .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndFirstSibling
member.summary: Gets the window of the same type that is highest in the Z order. If this is a top-level window, gets first top-level window, else gets first control of the same direct parent. If this is the first, returns this, not default(Wnd). Calls API GetWindow(this, GW_HWNDFIRST).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndLastSibling
member.summary: Gets the window of the same type that is lowest in the Z order. If this is a top-level window, gets last top-level window, else gets last control of the same direct parent. If this is the last, returns this, not default(Wnd). Calls API GetWindow(this, GW_HWNDLAST).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndNext
member.summary: Gets the window of the same type that is next (below this) in the Z order. If this is a top-level window, gets next top-level window, else gets next control of the same direct parent. If this is the last, returns default(Wnd). Calls API GetWindow(this, GW_HWNDNEXT).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndPrev
member.summary: Gets the window of the same type that is previous (above this) in the Z order. If this is a top-level window, gets previous top-level window, else gets previous control of the same direct parent. If this is the first, returns default(Wnd). Calls API GetWindow(this, GW_HWNDPREV).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndFirstChild
member.summary: Gets the child control at the top of the Z order. Returns default(Wnd) if no children. The same as WndChild(0). Calls API GetWindow(this, GW_CHILD).
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndLastChild
member.summary: Gets the child control at the bottom of the Z order. Returns default(Wnd) if no children.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WndChild(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the child control at the specified position in the Z order. Returns default(Wnd) if no children or if index is invalid.
member.param: 0-based index of the child control in the Z order.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.WndActive
member.summary: Gets the active (foreground) window. Calls API GetForegroundWindow. Returns default(Wnd) if there is no active window; more info: .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsActive
member.summary: Returns true if this window is the active (foreground) window.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.LibIsActiveOrNoActiveAndThisIsWndRoot
member.summary: Returns true if this window is the active (foreground) window. If this is , returns true if there is no active window.

member.summary: Returns true if w contains a non-zero special handle value (see ). Note that HWND_TOP is 0.

member.name: T:Au.Registry_

member.name: F:Au.Registry_.AuKey
member.summary: Default registry key, used when the key argument is null or @"\" or starts with @"\".

member.name: M:Au.Registry_.ParseKeyString(System.String@)
member.summary: Parses registry key string and returns hive as RegistryKey. If key starts with "HKEY_", removes hive name from it and returns that hive. For example, if key is @"HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Test", sets key=@"Software\Test" and returns Registry.LocalMachine. Else if key is null or @"\", sets key=Registry_.AuKey (@"Software\Au") and returns Registry.CurrentUser. Else if key starts with @"\", prepends Registry_.AuKey (@"Software\Au") and returns Registry.CurrentUser. Else just returns Registry.CurrentUser. Valid hive names: "HKEY_CURRENT_USER", "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE", "HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT", "HKEY_USERS", "HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA" or "HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG".
member.param: Registry key. Can start with a hive name.
member.exception: 'key' starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.

member.name: M:Au.Registry_.Open(System.String,Microsoft.Win32.RegistryKey)
member.summary: Opens a key for read access. Returns null if the key does not exist. Uses .
member.param: Registry key. See
If not null, the 'key' argument is a subkey of this key or hive; if the 'key' argument is null or "", the function just returns parentKeyOrHive.
member.exception: 'key' starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.
The user does not have the permissions required to read the registry key.

member.name: M:Au.Registry_.CreateOrOpen(System.String,Microsoft.Win32.RegistryKey)
member.summary: Creates a new key or opens an existing key for write access. Uses .
member.param: Registry key. See

member.exception: 'key' starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.
The user does not have the permissions required to create or open the registry key.
parentKeyOrHive was not opened with write access.

member.summary: Gets file icon. Extracts icon directly from the file, or gets shell icon, depending on file type, icon index, flags etc. Calls and converts to Bitmap. Returns null if failed, for example if the file does not exist. Later call Dispose().
member.param: Can be: Path of any file or folder. URL, like "http://..." or "mailto:a@b.c" or "file:///path". ITEMIDLIST like ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST". It can be of any file, folder, URL or virtual object like Control Panel. See . Shell object parsing name, like @"::{CLSID-1}\::{CLSID-2}" or "shell:AppsFolder\WinStoreAppId". File type like ".txt" or URL protocol like "http:". If it is a file containing multiple icons (eg exe, dll), can be specified icon index like "path,index" or native icon resource id like "path,-id". If not full path, the function will look in . Supports environment variables (see ).
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.

member.name: T:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons
member.summary: Gets file icons asynchronously. Use to avoid waiting until all icons are extracted before displaying them in a UI (menu etc). Instead you show the UI without icons, and then asynchronously receive icons when they are extracted. At first call for each file. Then call GetAllAsync. Create a callback function of type and pass its delegate to GetAllAsync.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons.Add(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Adds a file path to an internal collection.
member.param: File path etc to pass to .
Something to pass to your callback function together with icon handle for this file.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons.Add(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Au.Icons.AsyncIn})
member.summary: Adds multiple file paths to an internal collection. The same as calling Add(string, object) multiple times. This function copies the list.

member.name: P:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of items added with Add(). GetAllAsync() sets it = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons.GetAllAsync(Au.Icons.AsyncCallback,System.Int32,Au.Types.GIFlags,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts getting icons of files added with Add(). After this function returns, icons are asynchronously extracted with , and callback called with icon handle (or default(IntPtr) if failed). The callback is called in this thread. This thread must have a message loop (eg Application.Run()). If you'll need more icons, you can call Add() and GetAllAsync() again with the same AsyncIcons instance, even if getting old icons if still not finished.
member.param: A callback function delegate.
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.
Something to pass to callback functions.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons.Clear
member.summary: Clears the internal collection of file paths added with Add().

member.name: M:Au.Icons.AsyncIcons.Cancel
member.summary: Stops getting icons and calling callback functions.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.FileIconCache.GetImage(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets file icon as Bitmap. If it is in the memory cache, gets it from there. Else if it is in the file cache, gets it from there and adds to the memory cache. Else gets from file (uses and adds to the file cache and to the memory cache. Returns null if GetFileIconImage failed, eg file does not exist.
member.param: Any file or folder.

Get file type icon, depending on filename extension. Use this to avoid getting separate image object for each file of same type. This is ignored if filename extension is ".ico" or ".exe" or starts with ".exe," or ".dll,".
member.remarks: Thread-safe. The variable can be static, and this function can be called from any thread without locking.

member.name: T:Au.Perf
member.summary: Code speed measurement. Easier to use than System.Stopwatch class. Stores data in shared memory, therefore works across appdomains.

member.name: T:Au.Perf.Inst
member.summary: The same as Perf class, but allows to have multiple independent speed measurements. Stores data int the variable, not in shared memory like Perf class.

member.name: P:Au.Perf.Inst.Incremental
member.summary: If true, times of each new First/Next/Next... measurement are added to previous measurement times. Finally you can call Write() or Times to get the sums. Usually used to measure code in loops. See example.

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.First
member.summary: Stores current time in the first element of an internal array.

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.First(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls SpinCPU(spinCpuMS) and .

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.First(System.Int32,System.Action[])
member.summary: Calls SpinCPU(spinCpuMS, codes) and .

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.Next(System.Char)
member.summary: Stores current time in next element of an internal array. Don't call Next() more than 16 times after First(), because the array has fixed size.
member.param: A character to mark that time in the results string, like "A=150".

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.Write
member.summary: Formats a string from time values collected by calling First() and Next(), and shows it in the output. The string contains the number of microseconds of each code execution between calling First() and each Next().

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.NW(System.Char)
member.summary: Calls and .
member.param: A character to mark that time in the results string, like "A=150".

member.name: P:Au.Perf.Inst.Times
member.summary: Formats a string from time values collected by calling First() and Next(). The string contains the number of microseconds of each code execution between calling First() and each Next().

member.name: P:Au.Perf.Inst.TimeTotal
member.summary: Gets the number of microseconds between First() and the last Next().

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.Execute(System.Int32,System.Action)
member.summary: Executes code (lambda) nTimes times, and then calls Next().

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.ExecuteMulti(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Action[])
member.summary: nTimesAll times executes this code: First(); foreach(Action a in codes) Execute(nTimesEach, a); Write();.

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Inst.SpinCPU(System.Int32,System.Action[])
member.summary: Repeatedly executes codes (zero or more lambda functions) for the specified number of milliseconds.

member.name: P:Au.Perf.Incremental
member.summary: If true, times of each new First/Next/Next... measurement are added to previous measurement times. Finally you can call Write() or Times to get the sums. Usually used to measure code in loops. See example.

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Next(System.Char)
member.summary: Stores current time in next element of an internal array. Don't call Next() more than 16 times after First(), because the array has fixed size.
member.param: A character to mark that time in the results string, like "A=150".

member.name: M:Au.Perf.Write
member.summary: Formats a string from time values collected by calling First() and Next(), and shows it in the output. The string contains the number of microseconds of each code execution between calling First() and each Next(). Example: Perf.First(100); CODE1; Perf.Next(); CODE2; Perf.Next(); Perf.Write(); //speed: timeOfCODE1 timeOfCODE2.

member.name: M:Au.Perf.NW(System.Char)
member.summary: Calls and . You can use Perf.NW(); instead of Perf.Next(); Perf.Write();.
member.param: A character to mark that time in the results string, like "A=150".

member.name: M:Au.Perf.SpinCPU(System.Int32,System.Action[])
member.summary: Repeatedly executes codes (zero or more lambda functions) for the specified number of milliseconds (recommended 100 or more). Can be called before measuring code speed, because after some idle time CPU may need to work for some time to gain full speed.
